segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Come in!” said he.

events.text_segment:
It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence. All day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so that even here in the heart of great, hand-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routine of life and to recognise the presence of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars of his civilisation, like untamed beasts in a cage. As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind cried and sobbed like a child in the chimney. Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexing his records of crime, while I at the other was deep in one of Clark Russell’s fine sea-stories until the howl of the gale from without seemed to blend with the text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of the sea waves. My wife was on a visit to her mother’s, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quarters at Baker Street.
“Why,” said I, glancing up at my companion, “that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? Some friend of yours, perhaps?”
“Except yourself I have none,” he answered. “I do not encourage visitors.”
“A client, then?”
“If so, it is a serious case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. But I take it that it is more likely to be some crony of the landlady’s.”
Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjecture, however, for there came a step in the passage and a tapping at the door. He stretched out his long arm to turn the lamp away from himself and towards the vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.
“Come in!” said he.

The wind howled through the narrow streets of London, rattling windows and tearing at the loose shutters. Sherlock Holmes sat in his Baker Street apartment, meticulously examining a peculiar piece of evidence that had been brought to him by a distressed client. The case, shrouded in mystery, involved a series of strange occurrences that defied conventional explanation.

Holmes's keen eyes flicked over the item—a small, intricately carved locket—before he looked up, his expression contemplative. "This, my dear Watson, is no ordinary trinket. Its origins are as obscure as the fog that now envelops our city."

Watson, ever eager to assist, leaned forward. "What do you make of it, Holmes?"

Holmes paused, considering. "The craftsmanship suggests a foreign origin, perhaps from the East. But more intriguing is the inscription inside, which appears to be a cipher."

He grabbed his coat and deerstalker, ready to venture into the stormy night. The wind's fury was nothing compared to the storm of clues Holmes was about to unravel. With a determined stride, he stepped out into the swirling darkness, the locket clenched tightly in his hand, as the city of London braced itself for the revelations to come.

events.title: John Openshaw Arrives Seeking Help
detailed_summary: A young man, around twenty-two, well-dressed but soaked from the storm, enters the room.
He appears refined but pale and anxious under the lamplight.
He apologizes for intruding and bringing the weather inside.
Holmes offers to take his wet coat and umbrella, deducing from the mud on his shoes that he has traveled from Horsham in the south-west.
The visitor confirms he is from Horsham and states the clay and chalk mixture on his shoes is indeed distinctive.
He declares he has come seeking advice and help.
Holmes remarks that advice is easily obtained, but help is not always so simple.
The young man reveals he has heard of Holmes through Major Prendergast, whom Holmes saved during the Tankerville Club scandal involving cheating at cards.
He relays the Major's assertion that Holmes can solve anything, which Holmes modestly disputes, admitting he has been defeated four times.

The visitor contrasts these few failures with Holmes's many successes, prompting Holmes to invite him to share the details of his case, assuring him that unusual cases are his specialty as the 'last court of appeal'.
The young man expresses doubt that even Holmes has encountered a mystery as strange as his family's experiences.
Holmes's interest is piqued, and he asks for the essential facts from the beginning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important.”

events.text_segment:
The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing. The streaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof told of the fierce weather through which he had come. He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I could see that his face was pale and his eyes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.
“I owe you an apology,” he said, raising his golden pince-nez to his eyes. “I trust that I am not intruding. I fear that I have brought some traces of the storm and rain into your snug chamber.”
“Give me your coat and umbrella,” said Holmes. “They may rest here on the hook and will be dry presently. You have come up from the south-west, I see.”
“Yes, from Horsham.”
“That clay and chalk mixture which I see upon your toe caps is quite distinctive.”
“I have come for advice.”
“That is easily got.”
“And help.”
“That is not always so easy.”
“I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes. I heard from Major Prendergast how you saved him in the Tankerville Club scandal.”
“Ah, of course. He was wrongfully accused of cheating at cards.”
“He said that you could solve anything.”
“He said too much.”
“That you are never beaten.”
“I have been beaten four times—three times by men, and once by a woman.”
“But what is that compared with the number of your successes?”
“It is true that I have been generally successful.”
“Then you may be so with me.”
“I beg that you will draw your chair up to the fire and favour me with some details as to your case.”
“It is no ordinary one.”
“None of those which come to me are. I am the last court of appeal.”
“And yet I question, sir, whether, in all your experience, you have ever listened to a more mysterious and inexplicable chain of events than those which have happened in my own family.”
“You fill me with interest,” said Holmes. “Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important.”

The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing. He was soaked from head to foot, and his clothes clung to him as if he had just come in from a storm. He looked around the room with a certain hesitancy, then stepped forward and apologized for intruding and for bringing the weather inside.

Holmes, who was sitting by the fire, rose to his feet and took the young man's coat and umbrella. From the mud on his shoes, Holmes deduced that he had traveled from Horsham in the south-west. The visitor confirmed this, adding that the clay and chalk mixture on his shoes was quite distinctive.

"I have come to seek your advice and help," he said, his voice trembling slightly.

Holmes smiled gently. "Advice is easily obtained, but help is not always so simple," he replied.

The young man then explained that he had heard of Holmes through Major Prendergast, whom Holmes had previously helped during the Tankerville Club scandal involving cheating at cards. The Major had told him that Holmes could solve anything, which Holmes modestly disputed, mentioning that he had been defeated four times.

The visitor contrasted these few failures with Holmes's many successes, and Holmes, intrigued, invited him to share the details of his case, assuring him that unusual cases were his specialty, as the 'last court of appeal.'

The young man hesitated for a moment, then expressed doubt that even Holmes had encountered a mystery as strange as his family's experiences. Holmes's interest was now fully piqued, and he urged the visitor to tell him everything from the beginning.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He carried himself with a certain nervous energy, his eyes darting around the room as if he were seeking something or someone. His voice was soft but clear when he spoke, and there was a hint of urgency in his manner. Sherlock Holmes, who had been quietly observing from his usual corner, leaned forward slightly, his keen eyes fixed on the visitor. The young man hesitated for a moment before taking a step closer to the detective's desk.

"I am in need of your assistance, Mr. Holmes," he began, his tone betraying a hint of desperation. "My name is Charles McGregor, and I am a solicitor from the city. I have come across a matter that I believe requires your particular expertise."

Holmes nodded slightly, encouraging him to continue. "Please, Mr. McGregor, do not hesitate. Tell me what has brought you here today."

The young man took a deep breath and proceeded. "It concerns a case of theft, but not an ordinary one. A valuable document has gone missing from my client’s estate, and I am convinced that it is an inside job. The document in question is a sealed letter, containing sensitive information that could compromise my client’s reputation if it were to fall into the wrong hands."

Holmes listened intently, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. "And you suspect someone within the household?"

"Exactly. There are only a few people who had access to the study where the letter was kept. I have already interviewed them, but I am not satisfied with their explanations. That is why I have come to you."

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with interest. "A delicate matter indeed. I shall be glad to assist you. Tell me, Mr. McGregor, when was the document last seen?"

"It was secured in the cabinet last evening, and this morning it was gone. The household was in a state of quiet activity, and no one noticed anything unusual."

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "Very well. I will examine the scene and speak with the staff. Rest assured, Mr. McGregor, we shall uncover the truth."

The young solicitor looked relieved, a faint smile breaking through his anxious expression. Holmes’s sharp mind was already turning over the details, ready to unravel the mystery that lay before him.

events.title: Openshaw Details His Uncle Elias's History
detailed_summary: The young man introduces himself as John Openshaw and explains the problem is hereditary, requiring him to start his story with his family history.
He describes his grandfather's two sons: his Uncle Elias and his father Joseph.
His father Joseph ran a successful bicycle tire factory in Coventry before retiring.
Uncle Elias emigrated to America, became a successful planter in Florida, and served as a colonel in the Confederate army.
After the Civil War, Elias returned to his plantation for a few years before moving back to Europe around 1869 or 1870, settling near Horsham, Sussex.
His reasons for leaving America were reportedly his aversion to Black people and Republican policies extending suffrage.
Elias lived as a recluse in England, described as fierce, quick-tempered, foul-mouthed, and solitary.
He rarely left his house, preferring his garden or room, drank heavily, smoked constantly, and avoided all society, including his brother.
Elias took a liking to John when John was twelve (around 1878) and invited him to live with him.
Elias was kind to John in his own way, playing games when sober and eventually making sixteen-year-old John the master of the house, entrusting him with keys and responsibilities.
John had access to everything except one locked lumber-room in the attic, which Elias forbade anyone from entering.
John's curiosity led him to peek through the keyhole, but he only saw old trunks and bundles.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With a boy’s curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I was never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

events.text_segment:
The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze.
“My name,” said he, “is John Openshaw, but my own affairs have, as far as I can understand, little to do with this awful business. It is a hereditary matter; so in order to give you an idea of the facts, I must go back to the commencement of the affair.
“You must know that my grandfather had two sons—my uncle Elias and my father Joseph. My father had a small factory at Coventry, which he enlarged at the time of the invention of bicycling. He was a patentee of the Openshaw unbreakable tire, and his business met with such success that he was able to sell it and to retire upon a handsome competence.
“My uncle Elias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Florida, where he was reported to have done very well. At the time of the war he fought in Jackson’s army, and afterwards under Hood, where he rose to be a colonel. When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where he remained for three or four years. About 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, near Horsham. He had made a very considerable fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion to the negroes, and his dislike of the Republican policy in extending the franchise to them. He was a singular man, fierce and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthed when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition. During all the years that he lived at Horsham, I doubt if ever he set foot in the town. He had a garden and two or three fields round his house, and there he would take his exercise, though very often for weeks on end he would never leave his room. He drank a great deal of brandy and smoked very heavily, but he would see no society and did not want any friends, not even his own brother.
“He didn’t mind me; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was a youngster of twelve or so. This would be in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He begged my father to let me live with him and he was very kind to me in his way. When he was sober he used to be fond of playing backgammon and draughts with me, and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the tradespeople, so that by the time that I was sixteen I was quite master of the house. I kept all the keys and could go where I liked and do what I liked, so long as I did not disturb him in his privacy. There was one singular exception, however, for he had a single room, a lumber-room up among the attics, which was invariably locked, and which he would never permit either me or anyone else to enter. With a boy’s curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I was never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

"I don't know what to do," he admitted. "My sister is missing, and I fear something terrible has happened to her." Holmes leaned forward, his keen eyes narrowing. "Tell me everything from the beginning," he said softly. The young man took a deep breath and began to recount the events of the past few days, describing how his sister had received a mysterious letter, and how she had suddenly disappeared without a word. Holmes listened intently, occasionally asking pointed questions that revealed a web of secrets and motives. As the night wore on, Holmes's mind was already racing through possibilities, connecting dots that the young man could not see. Outside, the wind howled, but inside, the detective's thoughts were as sharp as ever. "We must act quickly," Holmes finally declared. "There is a pattern here, and I believe I know where she might be." The young man looked hopeful, clutching his hands together. "Where do we start?" Holmes stood up, grabbing his coat and hat. "To the docks," he said. "I have a suspicion that she was taken there, perhaps to meet someone. We shall find her before it's too late." As they hurried out into the cold night, Holmes's mind was already piecing together clues, each one bringing him closer to the truth. The case was complex, but Holmes's deductive skills were unmatched. They arrived at the harbor, where the shadows of ships and warehouses loomed large. Holmes examined the area carefully, noting footprints and disturbed debris. "This way," he whispered, leading the young man along a narrow alley. Suddenly, they heard muffled voices coming from behind a stack of crates. Holmes signaled for silence and crept closer. Peering around the corner, he saw a group of men huddled together, and in their midst, a young woman who looked frightened but determined. Holmes nodded to himself. "This is it," he said quietly. "We must act now." With a swift move, Holmes drew his revolver and stepped into view. "Stand back!" he commanded. The men froze, surprised by the sudden appearance of the detective. Holmes addressed them firmly. "Release the young lady and disperse. You are under arrest." The men, realizing they were caught, reluctantly backed away. Holmes approached the girl, who was trembling but unharmed. "Are you alright?" he asked gently. She nodded, tears in her eyes. "Thank you," she whispered. Holmes helped her to her feet and turned to the young man. "Your sister is safe now," he said. "Thanks to quick thinking and a keen eye. We shall escort her home." As they made their way back through the dark streets, Holmes reflected on the case. "It was a matter of following the clues," he said. "A simple letter, a hurried disappearance, and a hidden meeting place. All of it led us here." The young man expressed his gratitude, and Holmes smiled modestly. "Holmes's work is never done," he remarked. "But tonight, justice has been served." They reached the young woman's home, where her family awaited anxiously. Holmes explained the situation briefly, and the young woman was reunited with her loved ones. As Holmes and his companion prepared to leave, the young man looked at Holmes with admiration. "How do you do it?" he asked. Holmes chuckled softly. "Deduction, my dear sir. Observation and deduction. The key to solving any mystery." With that, they turned into the night, ready for the next adventure that awaited them.

events.title: The First Warning and Uncle Elias's Demise
detailed_summary: In March 1883, Uncle Elias received a rare letter with a Pondicherry postmark.
Upon opening it, five dried orange pips fell out.

John's initial amusement turned to horror at his uncle's reaction: Elias's face turned putty-colored, his eyes bulged, and he shrieked 'K. K. K.!', followed by 'My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!'
When John asked what was wrong, Elias responded 'Death' and retreated to his room.
John examined the envelope and found 'K K K' scrawled in red ink on the inner flap.
Later, John encountered his uncle coming downstairs with an old key (likely for the attic room) and a small brass cashbox.
Elias defiantly declared he would 'checkmate them' and instructed John to light a fire in his room and summon Fordham, the lawyer.
When the lawyer arrived, John was called into the room, where the fire blazed and a mass of burned paper ashes lay in the grate next to the open, empty brass box.
John noticed with a start that the box lid bore the same 'K K K' inscription as the envelope.

Elias had John witness his will, leaving his estate (with all 'advantages and disadvantages') to John's father, advising that if it couldn't be enjoyed peacefully, it should be given to one's worst enemy.
John signed the will, deeply disturbed by the incident and filled with a lingering sense of dread.
Elias's behavior worsened; he drank more, became more reclusive, and had episodes of drunken frenzy, rushing outside with a revolver, shouting defiance, only to retreat back indoors in terror.
One night, during such an episode, Elias disappeared.
He was found dead, face down in a shallow, green-scummed garden pool.
With no signs of violence and considering Elias's eccentricity, the verdict was suicide.
John, however, doubted this, knowing his uncle's fear of death.
John's father inherited the estate and about £14,000.
Holmes interrupts to ask for the dates: the letter arrived March 10, 1883, and Elias died seven weeks later on May 2nd.
Holmes thanks Openshaw and asks him to continue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Thank you. Pray proceed.”

events.text_segment:
“One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate. It was not a common thing for him to receive letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends of any sort. ‘From India!’ said he as he took it up, ‘Pondicherry postmark! What can this be?’ Opening it hurriedly, out there jumped five little dried orange pips, which pattered down upon his plate. I began to laugh at this, but the laugh was struck from my lips at the sight of his face. His lip had fallen, his eyes were protruding, his skin the colour of putty, and he glared at the envelope which he still held in his trembling hand, ‘K. K. K.!’ he shrieked, and then, ‘My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!’
“‘What is it, uncle?’ I cried.
“‘Death,’ said he, and rising from the table he retired to his room, leaving me palpitating with horror. I took up the envelope and saw scrawled in red ink upon the inner flap, just above the gum, the letter K three times repeated. There was nothing else save the five dried pips. What could be the reason of his overpowering terror? I left the breakfast-table, and as I ascended the stair I met him coming down with an old rusty key, which must have belonged to the attic, in one hand, and a small brass box, like a cashbox, in the other.
“‘They may do what they like, but I’ll checkmate them still,’ said he with an oath. ‘Tell Mary that I shall want a fire in my room to-day, and send down to Fordham, the Horsham lawyer.’
“I did as he ordered, and when the lawyer arrived I was asked to step up to the room. The fire was burning brightly, and in the grate there was a mass of black, fluffy ashes, as of burned paper, while the brass box stood open and empty beside it. As I glanced at the box I noticed, with a start, that upon the lid was printed the treble K which I had read in the morning upon the envelope.
“‘I wish you, John,’ said my uncle, ‘to witness my will. I leave my estate, with all its advantages and all its disadvantages, to my brother, your father, whence it will, no doubt, descend to you. If you can enjoy it in peace, well and good! If you find you cannot, take my advice, my boy, and leave it to your deadliest enemy. I am sorry to give you such a two-edged thing, but I can’t say what turn things are going to take. Kindly sign the paper where Mr. Fordham shows you.’
“I signed the paper as directed, and the lawyer took it away with him. The singular incident made, as you may think, the deepest impression upon me, and I pondered over it and turned it every way in my mind without being able to make anything of it. Yet I could not shake off the vague feeling of dread which it left behind, though the sensation grew less keen as the weeks passed and nothing happened to disturb the usual routine of our lives. I could see a change in my uncle, however. He drank more than ever, and he was less inclined for any sort of society. Most of his time he would spend in his room, with the door locked upon the inside, but sometimes he would emerge in a sort of drunken frenzy and would burst out of the house and tear about the garden with a revolver in his hand, screaming out that he was afraid of no man, and that he was not to be cooped up, like a sheep in a pen, by man or devil. When these hot fits were over, however, he would rush tumultuously in at the door and lock and bar it behind him, like a man who can brazen it out no longer against the terror which lies at the roots of his soul. At such times I have seen his face, even on a cold day, glisten with moisture, as though it were new raised from a basin.
“Well, to come to an end of the matter, Mr. Holmes, and not to abuse your patience, there came a night when he made one of those drunken sallies from which he never came back. We found him, when we went to search for him, face downward in a little green-scummed pool, which lay at the foot of the garden. There was no sign of any violence, and the water was but two feet deep, so that the jury, having regard to his known eccentricity, brought in a verdict of ‘suicide.’ But I, who knew how he winced from the very thought of death, had much ado to persuade myself that he had gone out of his way to meet it. The matter passed, however, and my father entered into possession of the estate, and of some £ 14,000, which lay to his credit at the bank.”
“One moment,” Holmes interposed, “your statement is, I foresee, one of the most remarkable to which I have ever listened. Let me have the date of the reception by your uncle of the letter, and the date of his supposed suicide.”
“The letter arrived on March 10, 1883. His death was seven weeks later, upon the night of May 2nd.”
“Thank you. Pray proceed.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate.

In the quiet of his study, Sherlock Holmes listened intently as John Openshaw recounted the strange events surrounding his uncle Elias. The letter, bearing a Pondicherry postmark, had contained five dried orange pips, which seemed innocuous at first. But Elias’s reaction was anything but.

As Elias opened the letter, his face turned a sickly color, his eyes bulged, and he shrieked, 'K. K. K.!' before crying out, 'My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!' John was alarmed and asked what was wrong, but Elias only responded with 'Death' and retreated to his room.

Examining the envelope, John found scrawled in red ink on the inner flap the initials 'K K K.' Later, he saw his uncle descending the stairs with an old key—probably for the attic—and a small brass cashbox. Elias declared he would 'checkmate them' and instructed John to light a fire in his room and summon Fordham, the lawyer.

When Fordham arrived, John was called into the room where a fire blazed, and in the grate lay a mass of burned paper ashes beside the open, empty brass box. To his shock, John noticed that the box lid bore the same 'K K K' inscription as the envelope.

Elias then had John witness his will, which left his estate—described as containing 'advantages and disadvantages'—to John's father, with a peculiar advice that if the estate could not be enjoyed peacefully, it should be given to one's worst enemy. John signed the will, disturbed and filled with a lingering dread.

Elias’s behavior grew more erratic; he drank more heavily, became reclusive, and had episodes of drunken frenzy, rushing outside with a revolver, shouting defiance, only to retreat indoors in terror. One night, during such an episode, Elias disappeared.

He was later found dead, face down in a shallow garden pool that was green with scum. With no signs of violence and considering Elias’s eccentricity, the verdict was suicide. However, John doubted this, knowing his uncle’s fear of death.

John’s father inherited the estate and about £14,000. Holmes interrupted to ask for the dates: the letter arrived on March 10, 1883, and Elias died seven weeks later, on May 2nd.

Holmes thanked Openshaw and asked him to continue.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherlock Holmes, who was sitting nearby, glanced up from his pipe and examined the letter with keen interest. The colonel, a stout man with a weathered face, looked at Holmes with a mixture of curiosity and concern. Holmes carefully broke the seal and unfolded the letter, his sharp eyes scanning the unfamiliar handwriting. As he read, his brow furrowed slightly, indicating that the contents were of some importance.

The letter was from a foreign correspondent, detailing a mysterious occurrence in a distant land. It spoke of a series of strange events—disappearances, unexplained phenomena, and a secret society operating in the shadows. Holmes listened intently as the colonel explained that the letter had arrived unexpectedly, and that it might hold the key to a puzzle that had been troubling him.

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. "This is indeed intriguing," he said slowly. "The language is formal, yet there is an undercurrent of urgency. It appears that the writer fears for his safety, and perhaps for others as well."

The colonel nodded. "I thought it might be something worth investigating. The letter mentions a hidden location, a place called the 'Black Lotus,' which is supposed to be a meeting point for this secret society."

Holmes's eyes sparkled with interest. "The Black Lotus, you say? A most evocative name. It suggests something clandestine and perhaps dangerous. We must consider the possibility that this society is involved in illicit activities—perhaps smuggling, espionage, or worse."

He paused, then continued, "We should gather more information. Do you have any other correspondence or details that might shed light on this matter?"

The colonel reached into his pocket and produced a small bundle of papers. Among them was a map, marked with various symbols and annotations. Holmes examined it carefully, noting the peculiar markings and the location indicated near the outskirts of London.

"This map could be crucial," Holmes said. "It appears to point to an abandoned warehouse, which might serve as the meeting place. We should visit the site under the cover of darkness."

The following evening, Holmes and the colonel made their way through the foggy streets of London, approaching the designated location. The warehouse was old and dilapidated, its windows boarded up and its door slightly ajar. Holmes drew his revolver and signaled for silence as they entered.

Inside, the air was thick with dust and the scent of decay. Holmes's eyes quickly adjusted to the dim light, and he moved cautiously, listening for any sounds. Suddenly, a faint murmur reached his ears, and he signaled to the colonel to stay back.

Peering through a crack in the wall, Holmes saw a group of men gathered around a table, engaged in a heated discussion. They were dressed in dark clothing, and some wore masks. On the table lay a strange object, covered by a cloth.

Holmes's mind raced to interpret the scene. It was clear that this was indeed a clandestine meeting. He noted the symbols on the walls—strange glyphs and signs that seemed to be part of some secret code.

He decided to act. Carefully, he withdrew his revolver and prepared to confront the group, but he paused, considering the best course of action. Instead, he decided to gather more evidence before making any move.

Over the next few days, Holmes and the colonel continued their investigation, following leads and deciphering the symbols. Holmes discovered that the secret society was involved in smuggling valuable artifacts, using the Black Lotus as a meeting point.

He also learned that the society was planning a major operation, which could have serious repercussions if uncovered. Holmes devised a plan to infiltrate the group and gather concrete evidence.

On the night of the planned operation, Holmes and the colonel returned to the warehouse, this time with a small team of trusted officers. Holmes managed to blend in with the group, using his keen observation skills to identify the key members.

As the operation unfolded, Holmes was able to intercept the shipment and apprehend the leaders of the society. The artifacts were recovered, and the network was dismantled.

The case was closed, and Holmes's reputation as a master detective was further cemented. The mysterious letter from the foreign correspondent had led to a significant breakthrough, revealing the hidden world of secret societies operating beneath the surface of London.

Holmes reflected on the case, noting that sometimes the smallest clues—like a foreign stamp—could open the door to the most complex mysteries. His keen mind and relentless pursuit of truth had once again uncovered the hidden truths lurking in the shadows.

events.text_segment:
“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. We found the brass box there, although its contents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, with the initials of K. K. K. repeated upon it, and ‘Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register’ written beneath. These, we presume, indicated the nature of the papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw. For the rest, there was nothing of much importance in the attic save a great many scattered papers and note-books bearing upon my uncle’s life in America. Some of them were of the war time and showed that he had done his duty well and had borne the repute of a brave soldier. Others were of a date during the reconstruction of the Southern states, and were mostly concerned with politics, for he had evidently taken a strong part in opposing the carpet-bag politicians who had been sent down from the North.
“Well, it was the beginning of ’84 when my father came to live at Horsham, and all went as well as possible with us until the January of ’85. On the fourth day after the new year I heard my father give a sharp cry of surprise as we sat together at the breakfast-table. There he was, sitting with a newly opened envelope in one hand and five dried orange pips in the outstretched palm of the other one. He had always laughed at what he called my cock-and-bull story about the colonel, but he looked very scared and puzzled now that the same thing had come upon himself.
“‘Why, what on earth does this mean, John?’ he stammered.
“My heart had turned to lead. ‘It is K. K. K.,’ said I.
“He looked inside the envelope. ‘So it is,’ he cried. ‘Here are the very letters. But what is this written above them?’
“‘Put the papers on the sundial,’ I read, peeping over his shoulder.
“‘What papers? What sundial?’ he asked.
“‘The sundial in the garden. There is no other,’ said I; ‘but the papers must be those that are destroyed.’
“‘Pooh!’ said he, gripping hard at his courage. ‘We are in a civilised land here, and we can’t have tomfoolery of this kind. Where does the thing come from?’
“‘From Dundee,’ I answered, glancing at the postmark.
“‘Some preposterous practical joke,’ said he. ‘What have I to do with sundials and papers? I shall take no notice of such nonsense.’
“‘I should certainly speak to the police,’ I said.
“‘And be laughed at for my pains. Nothing of the sort.’
“‘Then let me do so?’
“‘No, I forbid you. I won’t have a fuss made about such nonsense.’
“It was in vain to argue with him, for he was a very obstinate man. I went about, however, with a heart which was full of forebodings.
“On the third day after the coming of the letter my father went from home to visit an old friend of his, Major Freebody, who is in command of one of the forts upon Portsdown Hill. I was glad that he should go, for it seemed to me that he was farther from danger when he was away from home. In that, however, I was in error. Upon the second day of his absence I received a telegram from the major, imploring me to come at once. My father had fallen over one of the deep chalk-pits which abound in the neighbourhood, and was lying senseless, with a shattered skull. I hurried to him, but he passed away without having ever recovered his consciousness. He had, as it appears, been returning from Fareham in the twilight, and as the country was unknown to him, and the chalk-pit unfenced, the jury had no hesitation in bringing in a verdict of ‘death from accidental causes.’ Carefully as I examined every fact connected with his death, I was unable to find anything which could suggest the idea of murder. There were no signs of violence, no footmarks, no robbery, no record of strangers having been seen upon the roads. And yet I need not tell you that my mind was far from at ease, and that I was well-nigh certain that some foul plot had been woven round him.
“In this sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it? I answer, because I was well convinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle’s life, and that the danger would be as pressing in one house as in another.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. Inside, he found an empty brass box bearing the initials K.K.K., and a label indicating that certain papers—letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register—had been destroyed. Among the papers, there were documents relating to my uncle's time in America, including his war service and his opposition to certain post-war politicians in the South.

In early 1884, my father moved to Horsham, and life went on normally until January 1885. On the 4th of January, while at breakfast, he suddenly cried out in surprise, holding an envelope and five orange pips that had just been opened. His face showed fear, and he looked at me with a strange expression, despite having previously dismissed my story about the Colonel. He read the initials K.K.K. on the envelope and then above them, a message: 'Put the papers on the sundial.'

I was confused about which papers and which sundial he meant—whether the garden sundial or the destroyed papers—and he dismissed the message as 'tomfoolery' from Dundee, refusing to involve the police, fearing ridicule. He forbade me from contacting the police either.

I was deeply worried. Three days later, my father visited Major Freebody at Portsdown Hill. I felt relief, thinking he was safer away from home, but this proved false. On the second day of his absence, I received a telegram from the Major urging me to come at once. My father had fallen into a deep, unfenced chalk pit near Fareham while returning in the twilight, and he was found unconscious with a shattered skull. He died without regaining consciousness.

The jury ruled his death as 'accidental causes' due to the unfamiliar and unfenced terrain. Despite a thorough examination, I found no evidence of murder—no violence, footprints, robbery, or strangers reported. Yet I remained convinced that my father was a victim of a foul plot. I inherited the estate, keeping it because I believed the danger was connected to my uncle's past and would follow me regardless of where I went.

events.text_segment:
“It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. During that time I have lived happily at Horsham, and I had begun to hope that this curse had passed away from the family, and that it had ended with the last generation. I had begun to take comfort too soon, however; yesterday morning the blow fell in the very shape in which it had come upon my father.”
The young man took from his waistcoat a crumpled envelope, and turning to the table he shook out upon it five little dried orange pips.
“This is the envelope,” he continued. “The postmark is London—eastern division. Within are the very words which were upon my father’s last message: ‘K. K. K.’; and then ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’”
“What have you done?” asked Holmes.
“Nothing.”
“Nothing?”
“To tell the truth”—he sank his face into his thin, white hands—“I have felt helpless. I have felt like one of those poor rabbits when the snake is writhing towards it. I seem to be in the grasp of some resistless, inexorable evil, which no foresight and no precautions can guard against.”
“Tut! tut!” cried Sherlock Holmes. “You must act, man, or you are lost. Nothing but energy can save you. This is no time for despair.”
“I have seen the police.”
“Ah!”
“But they listened to my story with a smile. I am convinced that the inspector has formed the opinion that the letters are all practical jokes, and that the deaths of my relations were really accidents, as the jury stated, and were not to be connected with the warnings.”
Holmes shook his clenched hands in the air. “Incredible imbecility!” he cried.
“They have, however, allowed me a policeman, who may remain in the house with me.”
“Has he come with you to-night?”
“No. His orders were to stay in the house.”
Again Holmes raved in the air.
“Why did you come to me?” he said, “and, above all, why did you not come at once?”
“I did not know. It was only to-day that I spoke to Major Prendergast about my troubles and was advised by him to come to you.”
“It is really two days since you had the letter. We should have acted before this. You have no further evidence, I suppose, than that which you have placed before us—no suggestive detail which might help us?”
“There is one thing,” said John Openshaw. He rummaged in his coat pocket, and, drawing out a piece of discoloured, blue-tinted paper, he laid it out upon the table. “I have some remembrance,” said he, “that on the day when my uncle burned the papers I observed that the small, unburned margins which lay amid the ashes were of this particular colour. I found this single sheet upon the floor of his room, and I am inclined to think that it may be one of the papers which has, perhaps, fluttered out from among the others, and in that way has escaped destruction. Beyond the mention of pips, I do not see that it helps us much. I think myself that it is a page from some private diary. The writing is undoubtedly my uncle’s.”
Holmes moved the lamp, and we both bent over the sheet of paper, which showed by its ragged edge that it had indeed been torn from a book. It was headed, “March, 1869,” and beneath were the following enigmatical notices:
“4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.
“7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.
“9th. McCauley cleared.
“10th. John Swain cleared.
“12th. Visited Paramore. All well.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then.

Since that time, I had begun to hope that the curse which had haunted our family was finally broken. For a while, peace reigned, and I dared to believe that the terrible history was over. But yesterday morning, that hope was shattered. The threat reappeared in the same sinister form, reminding me that evil can never be fully eradicated.

In my trembling hand, I produced a crumpled envelope, and I shook five dried orange pips onto the table. I then showed Holmes the envelope, postmarked from the London eastern division, which contained a message: 'K. K. K.' and a note instructing, 'Put the papers on the sundial.' When Holmes inquired what I had done in response, I had to confess, 'Nothing.' I felt helpless, as if I were prey cornered by an inescapable evil, unable to escape or to act.

Holmes, with his characteristic sharpness, admonished me, urging immediate action to prevent my being lost to this menace. I explained that I had gone to the police, but they dismissed my story as a practical joke and considered the deaths of my relatives to be mere accidents. Holmes reacted with frustration, calling their imbecility 'incredible.'

I mentioned that the police had assigned an officer to stay at my house, but I had not accompanied him to London. Holmes, again exasperated, asked why I had not come to him immediately. I explained that I had only spoken to Major Prendergast that very day, who advised me to consult Holmes.

Holmes pointed out that two days had passed since the letter arrived, emphasizing the lost time. He then asked if I had any further details that might be suggestive. I remembered something: on the day my uncle burned the papers, I had noticed that the unburned edges of the documents were of a particular blue tint.

I produced a single sheet of discolored, blue-tinted paper I found on the floor of my uncle's room, which I believed might have escaped from the fire. I thought it could be a page from his private diary, written in his own hand, though I was unsure of its usefulness beyond mentioning pips.

Holmes examined the torn page, which was headed 'March, 1869.' It contained cryptic entries: '4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.', '7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.', '9th. McCauley cleared.', '10th. John Swain cleared.', '12th. Visited Paramore. All well.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I have often thought since that if I had been more attentive to his warnings, or if I had not been so absorbed in my own pursuits, perhaps I might have been able to save him. But it was not to be. The tragedy cast a long shadow over our family, and my mother, in her grief, withdrew from the world, leaving me to fend for myself. I was then a boy of twelve, and the loss of my father left a void that no words can adequately describe.

It was during this bleak period that I first encountered Sherlock Holmes. I had heard of his remarkable talents and his uncanny ability to solve the most perplexing mysteries, but I had never imagined that I would one day seek his counsel. It was a chance meeting, in a quiet corner of the Baker Street lodging where he resided, that changed the course of my life.

Holmes was then engaged in examining a peculiar set of footprints in the snow outside his window. His keen eyes noted every detail—the size, the depth, the pattern—and he deduced that the footprints belonged to a man of medium height, wearing heavy boots, who had recently been in a struggle. I watched in awe as he pieced together the story behind the footprints, revealing a clandestine meeting that had taken place the previous night.

It was this incident that prompted me to confide in him about my own troubles. I told him of my father's mysterious death, of the strange circumstances surrounding it, and of the strange occurrences that had begun to plague our household since that time. Holmes listened intently, his sharp mind already working through the details.

He asked me many questions—about my father's habits, his associates, any enemies he might have had. I recalled that my father had been a man of integrity, but he had also been involved in some delicate negotiations with a certain Mr. Rucastle, a local businessman. Holmes's interest was piqued at this mention, and he promised to look into the matter.

Over the following days, Holmes and I delved into the case together. Holmes's methods were meticulous; he examined documents, interviewed witnesses, and even visited the scene of the incident. His deductions were astonishing, often revealing truths that had remained hidden from everyone else.

One evening, Holmes summoned me to his rooms, his face grave but determined. He had uncovered a link between my father's death and a clandestine scheme involving forged documents and blackmail. It appeared that my father had stumbled upon this scheme and was silenced to keep the secret from coming to light.

The revelation was shocking, but it also brought a measure of relief. At last, I understood the true circumstances of my father's demise. Holmes's insight had not only solved the mystery but also provided a measure of justice.

From that day forward, I became Holmes's devoted friend and confidant. His brilliant mind and unwavering dedication to truth inspired me, and I resolved to follow his example. The case of my father's death marked the beginning of a lifelong friendship, and I have no doubt that without Holmes's extraordinary talents, the truth would have remained forever hidden.

events.title: Holmes Gives Urgent Instructions and Warnings
detailed_summary: Holmes quickly returns the diary page to Openshaw, stressing the need for immediate action without further discussion.
He instructs Openshaw to return home instantly.
The plan: place the diary page into the brass box along with a convincing note stating all other papers were burned by his uncle and this is the sole remaining one.
This box must then be placed immediately on the sundial as directed.
Holmes advises against seeking revenge for now, focusing first on removing the immediate danger to Openshaw.
The secondary goals are solving the mystery and punishing the culprits.
Openshaw, revitalized with hope, agrees to follow the advice precisely.
Holmes reiterates the urgency and warns Openshaw to be extremely careful, as he is undoubtedly in real and imminent danger.
Openshaw confirms he will travel back by train from Waterloo and that he is armed.
Holmes notes the streets will be crowded before 9 PM, offering some safety, but urges extreme caution.
Holmes states he will begin working on the case tomorrow, investigating in London, not Horsham, as the secret lies there.
Openshaw promises to report back in a day or two about the box and papers.
He shakes hands and departs into the stormy night.
Watson reflects on the wild story feeling as if it blew in with the storm and was reabsorbed by it.
Holmes sits silently by the fire for some time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

events.text_segment:
“Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “And now you must on no account lose another instant. We cannot spare time even to discuss what you have told me. You must get home instantly and act.”
“What shall I do?”
“There is but one thing to do. It must be done at once. You must put this piece of paper which you have shown us into the brass box which you have described. You must also put in a note to say that all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains. You must assert that in such words as will carry conviction with them. Having done this, you must at once put the box out upon the sundial, as directed. Do you understand?”
“Entirely.”
“Do not think of revenge, or anything of the sort, at present. I think that we may gain that by means of the law; but we have our web to weave, while theirs is already woven. The first consideration is to remove the pressing danger which threatens you. The second is to clear up the mystery and to punish the guilty parties.”
“I thank you,” said the young man, rising and pulling on his overcoat. “You have given me fresh life and hope. I shall certainly do as you advise.”
“Do not lose an instant. And, above all, take care of yourself in the meanwhile, for I do not think that there can be a doubt that you are threatened by a very real and imminent danger. How do you go back?”
“By train from Waterloo.”
“It is not yet nine. The streets will be crowded, so I trust that you may be in safety. And yet you cannot guard yourself too closely.”
“I am armed.”
“That is well. To-morrow I shall set to work upon your case.”
“I shall see you at Horsham, then?”
“No, your secret lies in London. It is there that I shall seek it.”
“Then I shall call upon you in a day, or in two days, with news as to the box and the papers. I shall take your advice in every particular.” He shook hands with us and took his leave. Outside the wind still screamed and the rain splashed and pattered against the windows. This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "Thank you!" said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. "Now, Mr. Openshaw, you must act at once. Take this diary page, place it in the brass box with the note explaining that all other papers were burned by your uncle and that this is the only remaining document. Then, you must put the box on the sundial as I have directed. Do not seek revenge now; your immediate concern is to remove yourself from danger. The true goal is to solve the mystery and bring the culprits to justice. Be very careful, for you are in real and imminent peril. I advise you to return by train from Waterloo, and carry arms for your protection. The streets will be crowded before nine, which offers some safety, but caution is essential. I will begin my investigation tomorrow, focusing on London, where the secret lies, not Horsham. Report back to me in a day or two about the box and papers. Now go, and stay safe." Openshaw nodded, feeling a renewed sense of hope. He shook Holmes's hand and stepped out into the stormy night. Watson watched him depart, feeling as if the wild story had blown in with the storm and was now being swept away by it. Holmes sat silently by the fire, lost in thought.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He looked at her with a keen, assessing gaze, his sharp eyes missing nothing. "You have done well to come to me with this matter," he said, his voice calm and measured. "Now, tell me everything from the beginning, and do not omit a single detail. Every piece of information could be vital in solving this perplexing case."

The lady nodded, her hands trembling slightly as she took a seat opposite Holmes. She recounted her story: how she had received an anonymous letter warning her of impending danger, and how she had found her belongings disturbed the very night before. Holmes listened intently, his brow furrowing as he absorbed each word.

"And you suspect no one?" he inquired.

"No, sir. I have no enemies that I know of," she replied softly.

Holmes leaned back, tapping his fingers together thoughtfully. "This letter, did it contain any peculiar marks or handwriting?"

"Yes, it was written in a hurried scrawl, with a strange symbol at the bottom—a circle with a line through it."

"Interesting," Holmes murmured. "A symbol can often be a clue to the sender's identity."

He stood up abruptly, pacing the room as he considered the case. "Mrs. Carter, I believe this is more than a simple threat. It appears to be a warning, perhaps from someone who wishes to intimidate you or perhaps to test your reactions."

"What should I do?" she asked, her voice trembling.

"Remain calm and do not alter your routine. I will look into this matter further. In the meantime, I suggest you keep this letter in a safe place and avoid discussing it with anyone else."

Holmes turned to Watson. "Watson, I shall need your assistance in examining the letter and the symbol."

"Of course," Watson replied.

Holmes took the letter and examined the symbol carefully. "This mark resembles a sign used by a certain clandestine group, but I cannot be certain without further investigation."

He then looked at the lady kindly. "Rest assured, Mrs. Carter, we will do our utmost to uncover the truth behind this threat."

As she left, Holmes and Watson exchanged a glance, both aware that this was only the beginning of a complex and intriguing case, one that would test their skills and deductive powers to the fullest.

events.title: Holmes Deduces the K.K.K.'s Identity and Method
detailed_summary: After Openshaw leaves, Holmes lights his pipe and reflects, remarking to Watson that this case is among their most fantastic, possibly rivaling the Sign of Four.
He feels Openshaw is in even greater peril than the Sholtos.
When Watson asks about the nature of the perils and the identity of K.K.K., Holmes explains his method of reasoning.
He states an ideal reasoner could deduce entire chains of events from a single fact, like Cuvier reconstructing an animal from one bone.
Achieving this requires utilizing all relevant knowledge, which Holmes has endeavored to acquire for his work.

Watson recalls his earlier analysis of Holmes's knowledge limitations (zero in philosophy, astronomy, politics; variable botany; profound geology of local mud; eccentric chemistry; unsystematic anatomy; unique crime/sensational lit; skilled violinist, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, self-poisoner).
Holmes reaffirms his principle of keeping only useful knowledge readily accessible.
Turning to the case, Holmes requests the 'K' volume of the American Encyclopædia.
He posits Colonel Openshaw must have had a strong reason to leave America and his Florida life for seclusion in England, suggesting fear.
The threatening letters confirm this fear.
Holmes notes the postmarks: Pondicherry, Dundee, East London – all seaports.
Watson deduces the writer was likely on a ship.
Holmes agrees, calling it a clue.

He dismisses Watson's suggestion of distance alone, pointing out the letter also traveled faster.

Holmes presumes the perpetrators are on a sailing ship, sending the warning ahead; the seven weeks from Pondicherry represented the time difference between the faster mail boat carrying the letter and the slower sailing vessel carrying the senders.

Watson exclaims in horror.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. Then he lit his pipe, and leaning back in his chair he watched the blue smoke-rings as they chased each other up to the ceiling.
“I think, Watson,” he remarked at last, “that of all our cases we have had none more fantastic than this.”
“Save, perhaps, the Sign of Four.”
“Well, yes. Save, perhaps, that. And yet this John Openshaw seems to me to be walking amid even greater perils than did the Sholtos.”
“But have you,” I asked, “formed any definite conception as to what these perils are?”
“There can be no question as to their nature,” he answered.
“Then what are they? Who is this K. K. K., and why does he pursue this unhappy family?”
Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together. “The ideal reasoner,” he remarked, “would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce from it not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. As Cuvier could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly understood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and after. We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study which have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its highest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowledge; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days of free education and encyclopædias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment. It is not so impossible, however, that a man should possess all knowledge which is likely to be useful to him in his work, and this I have endeavoured in my case to do. If I remember rightly, you on one occasion, in the early days of our friendship, defined my limits in a very precise fashion.”
“Yes,” I answered, laughing. “It was a singular document. Philosophy, astronomy, and politics were marked at zero, I remember. Botany variable, geology profound as regards the mud-stains from any region within fifty miles of town, chemistry eccentric, anatomy unsystematic, sensational literature and crime records unique, violin-player, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner by cocaine and tobacco. Those, I think, were the main points of my analysis.”
Holmes grinned at the last item. “Well,” he said, “I say now, as I said then, that a man should keep his little brain-attic stocked with all the furniture that he is likely to use, and the rest he can put away in the lumber-room of his library, where he can get it if he wants it. Now, for such a case as the one which has been submitted to us to-night, we need certainly to muster all our resources. Kindly hand me down the letter K of the American Encyclopædia which stands upon the shelf beside you. Thank you. Now let us consider the situation and see what may be deduced from it. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong reason for leaving America. Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charming climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town. His extreme love of solitude in England suggests the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear of someone or something which drove him from America. As to what it was he feared, we can only deduce that by considering the formidable letters which were received by himself and his successors. Did you remark the postmarks of those letters?”
“The first was from Pondicherry, the second from Dundee, and the third from London.”
“From East London. What do you deduce from that?”
“They are all seaports. That the writer was on board of a ship.”
“Excellent. We have already a clue. There can be no doubt that the probability—the strong probability—is that the writer was on board of a ship. And now let us consider another point. In the case of Pondicherry, seven weeks elapsed between the threat and its fulfilment, in Dundee it was only some three or four days. Does that suggest anything?”
“A greater distance to travel.”
“But the letter had also a greater distance to come.”
“Then I do not see the point.”
“There is at least a presumption that the vessel in which the man or men are is a sailing-ship. It looks as if they always send their singular warning or token before them when starting upon their mission. You see how quickly the deed followed the sign when it came from Dundee. If they had come from Pondicherry in a steamer they would have arrived almost as soon as their letter. But, as a matter of fact, seven weeks elapsed. I think that those seven weeks represented the difference between the mail-boat which brought the letter and the sailing vessel which brought the writer.”
“It is possible.”
“More than that. It is probable. And now you see the deadly urgency of this new case, and why I urged young Openshaw to caution. The blow has always fallen at the end of the time which it would take the senders to travel the distance. But this one comes from London, and therefore we cannot count upon delay.”
“Good God!” I cried. “What can it mean, this relentless persecution?”
“The papers which Openshaw carried are obviously of vital importance to the person or persons in the sailing-ship. I think that it is quite clear that there must be more than one of them. A single man could not have carried out two deaths in such a way as to deceive a coroner’s jury. There must have been several in it, and they must have been men of resource and determination. Their papers they mean to have, be the holder of them who it may. In this way you see K. K. K. ceases to be the initials of an individual and becomes the badge of a society.”
“But of what society?”
“Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The room was quiet save for the crackling of the logs and the occasional pop of a coal. Outside, the London fog pressed against the windows, muffling the distant sounds of the city. Holmes's brow was furrowed in thought, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. Suddenly, he looked up, a spark of interest lighting his eyes.

"Watson," he began, his voice low but eager, "I believe we are on the verge of uncovering a most intriguing case. The clues, though subtle, are beginning to align."

I leaned forward, eager to hear more. "What have you deduced so far?"

Holmes paused, then gestured towards the fireplace. "The fire's glow reveals more than mere warmth. The way the coals are arranged suggests recent activity, perhaps a hurried departure. The ash is disturbed, indicating someone has been here not long ago."

He rose and moved to his desk, where he picked up a magnifying glass and a small notebook. "Let us consider the circumstances. A visitor, perhaps in distress or urgency, has been here. The pattern of footprints outside the window suggests someone was lurking nearby, watching or waiting."

I nodded, captivated by his reasoning. "And the missing items?"

"Ah, yes," Holmes said, turning to me with a keen look. "The theft of the documents from the study, I suspect, is connected. The thief was perhaps after something specific, something valuable enough to risk detection."

He paused, then added, "The key to solving this lies in understanding the motive and the perpetrator's identity. We must examine the clues carefully."

Holmes then proceeded to examine the room meticulously, noting the position of furniture, the scuff marks on the floor, and the faint traces of a hurried exit. His sharp eyes caught details that escaped my notice.

"Notice," he said, pointing to a smudge on the windowpane, "the smudge indicates someone pressed their hand here recently. The pattern of the smudge suggests a left-handed individual."

He then examined the fireplace again. "The ashes are not entirely cold, and the way the logs are arranged suggests someone was sitting here not long ago, perhaps contemplating their next move."

Holmes's gaze then fell upon a small torn piece of fabric caught on the edge of the rug. He carefully retrieved it and examined it with his pocket lens. "This fabric matches the lining of a coat I saw in the wardrobe earlier."

He looked at me with a triumphant smile. "The pieces are coming together. The thief was likely someone familiar with the household, perhaps a servant or a visitor."

Holmes then took out his pocket watch and checked the time. "We have a window of opportunity. The thief may return or attempt to cover their tracks. We must act swiftly."

He gathered his belongings and prepared to leave. "Watson, I believe the key to this mystery lies in the garden. The footprints outside are telling a story."

We stepped out into the foggy night, Holmes leading the way. The footprints in the damp earth showed a hurried pace, leading towards the alleyway. Holmes examined them carefully.

"The pattern indicates a person wearing soft-soled shoes, perhaps a woman. The direction suggests they are heading towards the river."

We followed the trail, Holmes's keen eyes never missing a detail. As we approached the riverbank, he paused, kneeling to examine a small object lying in the mud.

"A button," he said, holding it up. "From a coat similar to the one the thief was wearing."

Suddenly, a shadow moved in the distance. Holmes signaled for silence and crept closer. We saw a figure hurriedly discarding something into the water.

"There!" Holmes whispered, pointing. "The thief is attempting to destroy evidence."

He quickened his pace and called out, "Stop! Police!"

The figure froze, then turned to face us. It was a young woman, her face pale but determined.

"Please," she begged, "you must understand. I didn't mean to steal. I was desperate."

Holmes studied her intently. "Explain yourself."

She took a deep breath. "My brother is ill, and I needed money for his treatment. I thought I could retrieve the documents from the study and sell them quickly. I didn't want to hurt anyone, but I was cornered."

Holmes nodded slowly. "Your motives are clear, but your actions are unlawful. However, I believe your intentions were not malicious."

He turned to the police officers arriving on the scene. "Take her into custody, but treat her with compassion."

As the woman was led away, Holmes turned to me. "Watson, this case has been a fine example of deduction and understanding. The clues led us from the fire to the footprints, and finally to the truth behind the theft."

We returned to the house, where Holmes examined the recovered documents and the items the thief had discarded. The case was resolved, not just through logic, but through empathy and insight.

As we settled back by the fire, Holmes reflected, "In every mystery, there is a human story. Our role is to uncover the truth, but also to understand the motives that drive people to act as they do."

I looked at him with admiration. "Holmes, your mind is a marvel."

He smiled modestly. "It is merely a matter of paying close attention to the details that others overlook."

And so, the night drew to a close, with the case of the stolen documents and the mysterious visitor brought to a close, thanks to Holmes's extraordinary powers of deduction.

events.title: The Ku Klux Klan Connection Revealed
detailed_summary: Watson admits he has never heard of the Ku Klux Klan.
Holmes finds the entry in the American Encyclopædia he requested earlier.
He reads aloud the description: a terrible secret society formed by ex-Confederate soldiers post-Civil War, using terror for political ends, particularly against Black voters and opponents.
Their outrages were often preceded by symbolic warnings (oak leaves, melon seeds, orange pips).
Victims could recant or flee; defiance meant certain death, often in strange ways.
The organization was highly effective and elusive, flourishing for years despite government efforts.
It suddenly collapsed around 1869, though sporadic incidents continued.
Holmes points out the collapse coincided with Colonel Openshaw's departure from America with 'their papers', suggesting cause and effect.
He explains this makes it understandable why implacable members are tracking the family, as the register and diary likely implicate prominent Southern figures who want the documents destroyed.
He interprets the diary page Watson saw: 'sent the pips' meant sending the Klan warning; 'cleared' meant the targets left the country; 'visited' implied a sinister outcome for Paramore.
Holmes believes they can shed light on the matter and that Openshaw's only current chance is following his instructions.
Concluding the discussion for the night, Holmes asks for his violin to distract from the grim weather and human behavior.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I never have.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There is nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men.”

events.text_segment:
“I never have.”
Holmes turned over the leaves of the book upon his knee. “Here it is,” said he presently:
“‘Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblance to the sound produced by cocking a rifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiers in the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, notably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, principally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were opposed to its views. Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generally recognised shape—a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this the victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, death would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisation of the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in braving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the organisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the community in the South. Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadic outbreaks of the same sort since that date.’
“You will observe,” said Holmes, laying down the volume, “that the sudden breaking up of the society was coincident with the disappearance of Openshaw from America with their papers. It may well have been cause and effect. It is no wonder that he and his family have some of the more implacable spirits upon their track. You can understand that this register and diary may implicate some of the first men in the South, and that there may be many who will not sleep easy at night until it is recovered.”
“Then the page we have seen—”
“Is such as we might expect. It ran, if I remember right, ‘sent the pips to A, B, and C’—that is, sent the society’s warning to them. Then there are successive entries that A and B cleared, or left the country, and finally that C was visited, with, I fear, a sinister result for C. Well, I think, Doctor, that we may let some light into this dark place, and I believe that the only chance young Openshaw has in the meantime is to do what I have told him. There is nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men.”

events.title: Tragic News: John Openshaw Found Dead
detailed_summary: The following morning is clear and sunny.
Watson finds Holmes already at breakfast, anticipating a busy day investigating Openshaw's case.
Holmes plans to start his inquiries in the City, possibly going to Horsham later if needed.
While waiting for coffee, Watson glances at the newspaper and sees a headline that chills him.
He cries out to Holmes that he is too late.
Holmes, fearing the worst, calmly asks how it happened, though Watson sees he is deeply moved.
Watson reads the account titled 'Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge': between 9 and 10 PM the previous night, a police constable heard a cry for help and a splash near the bridge.
Due to the dark and stormy conditions, rescue attempts by the constable and passers-by failed.
The water-police later recovered the body, identified via an envelope in his pocket as John Openshaw of Horsham.
The newspaper conjectures he was rushing for the last train, missed his path in the dark, and fell from a steamboat landing stage.
The report states no signs of violence were found, concluding it was an unfortunate accident and highlighting the poor condition of riverside landings.
Holmes and Watson sit in silence; Holmes appears more shaken than Watson has ever seen him.
Holmes admits his pride is hurt, calling it a petty feeling but stating the case has become personal.
He vows, health permitting, to bring the gang to justice, lamenting that Openshaw came for help only to be sent to his death.
He paces the room agitatedly, wondering how the 'cunning devils' lured Openshaw to the Embankment, which wasn't on his direct route to Waterloo station.
He resolves to win in the long run and declares he is going out, intending to be his own police force and only involving them once his 'web' is spun.

events.text_segment:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. Sherlock Holmes was already at breakfast when I came down.
“You will excuse me for not waiting for you,” said he; “I have, I foresee, a very busy day before me in looking into this case of young Openshaw’s.”
“What steps will you take?” I asked.
“It will very much depend upon the results of my first inquiries. I may have to go down to Horsham, after all.”
“You will not go there first?”
“No, I shall commence with the City. Just ring the bell and the maid will bring up your coffee.”
As I waited, I lifted the unopened newspaper from the table and glanced my eye over it. It rested upon a heading which sent a chill to my heart.
“Holmes,” I cried, “you are too late.”
“Ah!” said he, laying down his cup, “I feared as much. How was it done?” He spoke calmly, but I could see that he was deeply moved.
“My eye caught the name of Openshaw, and the heading ‘Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.’ Here is the account:
“‘Between nine and ten last night Police-Constable Cook, of the H Division, on duty near Waterloo Bridge, heard a cry for help and a splash in the water. The night, however, was extremely dark and stormy, so that, in spite of the help of several passers-by, it was quite impossible to effect a rescue. The alarm, however, was given, and, by the aid of the water-police, the body was eventually recovered. It proved to be that of a young gentleman whose name, as it appears from an envelope which was found in his pocket, was John Openshaw, and whose residence is near Horsham. It is conjectured that he may have been hurrying down to catch the last train from Waterloo Station, and that in his haste and the extreme darkness he missed his path and walked over the edge of one of the small landing-places for river steamboats. The body exhibited no traces of violence, and there can be no doubt that the deceased had been the victim of an unfortunate accident, which should have the effect of calling the attention of the authorities to the condition of the riverside landing-stages.’”
We sat in silence for some minutes, Holmes more depressed and shaken than I had ever seen him.
“That hurts my pride, Watson,” he said at last. “It is a petty feeling, no doubt, but it hurts my pride. It becomes a personal matter with me now, and, if God sends me health, I shall set my hand upon this gang. That he should come to me for help, and that I should send him away to his death—!” He sprang from his chair and paced about the room in uncontrollable agitation, with a flush upon his sallow cheeks and a nervous clasping and unclasping of his long thin hands.
“They must be cunning devils,” he exclaimed at last. “How could they have decoyed him down there? The Embankment is not on the direct line to the station. The bridge, no doubt, was too crowded, even on such a night, for their purpose. Well, Watson, we shall see who will win in the long run. I am going out now!”
“To the police?”
“No; I shall be my own police. When I have spun the web they may take the flies, but not before.”
