events.text_segment:
The building was of grey, lichen-blotched stone, with a high central portion and two curving wings, like the claws of a crab, thrown out on each side. In one of these wings the windows were broken and blocked with wooden boards, while the roof was partly caved in, a picture of ruin. The central portion was in little better repair, but the right-hand block was comparatively modern, and the blinds in the windows, with the blue smoke curling up from the chimneys, showed that this was where the family resided. Some scaffolding had been erected against the end wall, and the stone-work had been broken into, but there were no signs of any workmen at the moment of our visit. Holmes walked slowly up and down the ill-trimmed lawn and examined with deep attention the outsides of the windows.
“This, I take it, belongs to the room in which you used to sleep, the centre one to your sister’s, and the one next to the main building to Dr. Roylott’s chamber?”
“Exactly so. But I am now sleeping in the middle one.”
“Pending the alterations, as I understand. By the way, there does not seem to be any very pressing need for repairs at that end wall.”
“There were none. I believe that it was an excuse to move me from my room.”
“Ah! that is suggestive. Now, on the other side of this narrow wing runs the corridor from which these three rooms open. There are windows in it, of course?”
“Yes, but very small ones. Too narrow for anyone to pass through.”
“As you both locked your doors at night, your rooms were unapproachable from that side. Now, would you have the kindness to go into your room and bar your shutters?”
Miss Stoner did so, and Holmes, after a careful examination through the open window, endeavoured in every way to force the shutter open, but without success. There was no slit through which a knife could be passed to raise the bar. Then with his lens he tested the hinges, but they were of solid iron, built firmly into the massive masonry. “Hum!” said he, scratching his chin in some perplexity, “my theory certainly presents some difficulties. No one could pass these shutters if they were bolted. Well, we shall see if the inside throws any light upon the matter.”
A small side door led into the whitewashed corridor from which the three bedrooms opened. Holmes refused to examine the third chamber, so we passed at once to the second, that in which Miss Stoner was now sleeping, and in which her sister had met with her fate. It was a homely little room, with a low ceiling and a gaping fireplace, after the fashion of old country-houses. A brown chest of drawers stood in one corner, a narrow white-counterpaned bed in another, and a dressing-table on the left-hand side of the window. These articles, with two small wicker-work chairs, made up all the furniture in the room save for a square of Wilton carpet in the centre. The boards round and the panelling of the walls were of brown, worm-eaten oak, so old and discoloured that it may have dated from the original building of the house. Holmes drew one of the chairs into a corner and sat silent, while his eyes travelled round and round and up and down, taking in every detail of the apartment.
“Where does that bell communicate with?” he asked at last pointing to a thick bell-rope which hung down beside the bed, the tassel actually lying upon the pillow.
“It goes to the housekeeper’s room.”
“It looks newer than the other things?”
“Yes, it was only put there a couple of years ago.”
“Your sister asked for it, I suppose?”
“No, I never heard of her using it. We used always to get what we wanted for ourselves.”
“Indeed, it seemed unnecessary to put so nice a bell-pull there. You will excuse me for a few minutes while I satisfy myself as to this floor.” He threw himself down upon his face with his lens in his hand and crawled swiftly backward and forward, examining minutely the cracks between the boards. Then he did the same with the wood-work with which the chamber was panelled. Finally he walked over to the bed and spent some time in staring at it and in running his eye up and down the wall. Finally he took the bell-rope in his hand and gave it a brisk tug.
“Why, it’s a dummy,” said he.
“Won’t it ring?”
“No, it is not even attached to a wire. This is very interesting. You can see now that it is fastened to a hook just above where the little opening for the ventilator is.”
“How very absurd! I never noticed that before.”
“Very strange!” muttered Holmes, pulling at the rope. “There are one or two very singular points about this room. For example, what a fool a builder must be to open a ventilator into another room, when, with the same trouble, he might have communicated with the outside air!”
“That is also quite modern,” said the lady.
“Done about the same time as the bell-rope?” remarked Holmes.
“Yes, there were several little changes carried out about that time.”
“They seem to have been of a most interesting character—dummy bell-ropes, and ventilators which do not ventilate. With your permission, Miss Stoner, we shall now carry our researches into the inner apartment.”
Dr. Grimesby Roylott’s chamber was larger than that of his step-daughter, but was as plainly furnished. A camp-bed, a small wooden shelf full of books, mostly of a technical character, an armchair beside the bed, a plain wooden chair against the wall, a round table, and a large iron safe were the principal things which met the eye. Holmes walked slowly round and examined each and all of them with the keenest interest.
“What’s in here?” he asked, tapping the safe.
“My stepfather’s business papers.”
“Oh! you have seen inside, then?”
“Only once, some years ago. I remember that it was full of papers.”
“There isn’t a cat in it, for example?”
“No. What a strange idea!”
“Well, look at this!” He took up a small saucer of milk which stood on the top of it.
“No; we don’t keep a cat. But there is a cheetah and a baboon.”
“Ah, yes, of course! Well, a cheetah is just a big cat, and yet a saucer of milk does not go very far in satisfying its wants, I daresay. There is one point which I should wish to determine.” He squatted down in front of the wooden chair and examined the seat of it with the greatest attention.
“Thank you. That is quite settled,” said he, rising and putting his lens in his pocket. “Hullo! Here is something interesting!”
The object which had caught his eye was a small dog lash hung on one corner of the bed. The lash, however, was curled upon itself and tied so as to make a loop of whipcord.
“What do you make of that, Watson?”
“It’s a common enough lash. But I don’t know why it should be tied.”
“That is not quite so common, is it? Ah, me! it’s a wicked world, and when a clever man turns his brains to crime it is the worst of all. I think that I have seen enough now, Miss Stoner, and with your permission we shall walk out upon the lawn.”

**Chapter VIII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE SPECKLED BAND**

The building was of grey, lichen-blotched stone, with a high central portion and two curving wings, like the claws of a crab, thrown out on each side. Watson described the exterior, noting the dilapidated state of the house. Holmes examined the windows of the left wing, which were boarded up and showed signs of recent scaffolding and workmen, indicating repairs in progress. The windows of the right wing, which appeared inhabited, showed signs of recent use, with curtains and furniture visible through the glass. The middle section, where Helen was to stay, had three bedrooms, each with its own window, and Holmes inspected each carefully.

He walked up and down the lawn, examining the windows of the three bedrooms. The windows of the left wing were boarded and under scaffolding, with workmen present. The right wing’s windows were intact and in use, with signs of habitation. The middle window, where Helen slept, was unboarded and appeared secure. Holmes tested the shutters of the middle window with his lens, examining the hinges and the way they fastened, confirming they were sturdy. He then looked at the roof of the left wing, noting the slate was loose and the chimney was cracked, but no signs of recent activity or repairs on the roof of the middle or right wing.

He then moved to the corridor, which ran behind the three bedrooms. The corridor was narrow, with small windows opening into the courtyard. Holmes examined the windows of the corridor, noting their small size and the fact that they were too small to permit entry. The corridor was quiet, with no sign of recent disturbance. The house was silent except for the distant sounds of workmen.

Holmes refused to examine the third chamber, the one Julia had occupied, citing that it was unnecessary. Instead, he directed his attention to the middle bedroom, which was sparsely furnished: a bed, a small table, a chair, and a few personal items. Holmes entered the room, moving silently, and examined every detail with his lens. He noted the position of the bed, the arrangement of the furniture, and the condition of the walls and floor.

He then observed a thick, relatively new bell-rope hanging by the bed. Helen confirmed it had been installed about two years ago but had never been used. Holmes examined the bell-rope closely, tugging it gently. It was a dummy, not connected to any wire, but fastened to a hook above a small ventilator near the ceiling. Helen expressed surprise, having never noticed this before.

Holmes then looked at the ventilator, which was small and square, with a grille that could be removed. He noted that it opened into the next room, which was Dr. Roylott’s larger chamber. Holmes remarked on the absurdity of such a ventilator opening into another room instead of outside, and learned it was a recent addition, installed at the same time as the bell-rope.

They moved to Dr. Roylott’s room, which was larger and plainly furnished: a camp-bed, a table, chairs, and a large iron safe. Holmes examined the safe’s contents—papers—and noted a saucer of milk on top. Helen confirmed they had no cat, only the cheetah and baboon. Holmes then examined the seat of a wooden chair near the safe, using his lens. His eyes caught a small dog lash curled into a loop hanging on the bedpost.

Holmes commented on the wickedness of a clever man turned criminal, and, after a thorough examination, declared he had seen enough. His expression was grim as they left the house, contemplating the deadly mystery that had been unraveled.

---

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion introduces a narrative perspective (e.g., “Watson described the dilapidated manor house”) that is not present in the original passage, which is more direct and observational.
- The sequence of events is sometimes altered, with some actions and discoveries presented out of order or summarized together rather than as a logical progression.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The building was of grey, lichen-blotched stone, with a high central portion and two curving wings, like the claws of a crab, thrown out on each side. It stood in the midst of a neglected garden, overgrown with weeds and tangled briars, giving it an air of abandonment and mystery. The windows, small and deeply set, looked out like dark, watchful eyes, and the heavy oak door was slightly ajar, as if inviting or warning those who approached.

Inside, the air was thick with dust and the scent of old wood and forgotten memories. The corridors stretched long and shadowed, lined with faded portraits whose eyes seemed to follow any intruder. At the end of one corridor, a faint light flickered, casting eerie shadows that danced upon the peeling wallpaper.

It was in this setting that Sherlock Holmes and I found ourselves, summoned by a letter that spoke of strange noises and unexplained phenomena. As we stepped into the dimly lit hall, Holmes paused, his keen eyes scanning the surroundings.

"This place has a story," he murmured, his voice barely above a whisper. "And I suspect it is a story that involves more than mere neglect."

We proceeded cautiously, Holmes leading the way, his hand resting lightly on his cane. The silence was oppressive, broken only by the faint creak of the floorboards beneath our feet. Suddenly, a soft sound echoed from the upper floor—a faint, shuffling noise, like someone or something moving behind a door.

"Did you hear that?" I asked.

"Indeed," Holmes replied, his eyes narrowing. "It appears we are not alone."

He moved towards a staircase that spiraled upward, each step creaking ominously under his weight. As we ascended, the noise grew louder, more distinct—a series of muffled footsteps and the rustling of papers.

Reaching the top, we found ourselves in a long corridor with several doors. Holmes paused, listening intently.

"The sound seems to come from the third door on the left," he said after a moment.

He gently pushed the door open, revealing a room cluttered with books, papers, and strange artifacts. In the corner, a figure was hunched over a desk, scribbling furiously.

"Who are you?" Holmes demanded.

The figure looked up, startled. It was an elderly man with a wild beard and spectacles perched on his nose.

"Ah! Mr. Holmes, I presume?" he said, adjusting his glasses. "I am Professor Alistair Crane, a historian and antiquarian. I have been researching the history of this estate."

"And what is the meaning of the noises?" I asked.

"Ah, those!" he exclaimed. "I have been trying to communicate with the spirits of the past, to uncover the secrets hidden within these walls."

Holmes raised an eyebrow. "Spirits, you say?"

"Yes, but not in the supernatural sense," the professor explained. "I believe there are rational explanations—hidden mechanisms, secret passages, or perhaps someone living here in disguise."

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "Your research is intriguing. May I see your notes?"

The professor eagerly handed over a sheaf of papers, filled with sketches and annotations.

As Holmes examined them, I noticed a faint smile playing on his lips.

"Professor," he said, "your work is meticulous. But I suspect the noises are caused by something more tangible."

Suddenly, a loud crash echoed from downstairs, causing us all to start.

"That confirms it," Holmes declared. "There is a visitor or intruder."

We hurried back down the stairs, Holmes leading the way. As we reached the ground floor, we saw a figure fleeing through the garden, disappearing into the night.

"After him!" Holmes commanded.

We gave chase, the figure darting between the shadows. He was quick, but Holmes was quicker, and soon we caught up, grabbing him by the arm.

"Who are you?" Holmes demanded.

The man struggled, then stopped and looked at us with wide eyes.

"My name is Jonathan Reed," he panted. "I am a thief, but I mean no harm. I was trying to find a hidden treasure rumored to be concealed within this estate."

Holmes studied him carefully. "And you thought to find it by breaking in?"

"Yes," Reed admitted. "I heard about the legend from an old servant, and I believed it was true."

Holmes released him. "Your story is plausible, but I advise you to leave this place and seek your fortune elsewhere."

Reed nodded gratefully and disappeared into the darkness.

Holmes turned to me. "This man was merely a misguided soul, driven by greed. But his intrusion has uncovered something more significant."

He led us back inside, where the professor was waiting anxiously.

"What have you discovered?" I asked.

"The secret lies beneath the floorboards," Holmes said. "There is a hidden compartment, concealed by a loose panel."

He knelt and pried open a section of the floor, revealing a small cavity filled with old coins, jewelry, and a sealed envelope.

"This must be the treasure the legend spoke of," Holmes declared.

He carefully examined the contents, then opened the envelope. Inside was a letter, written in elegant handwriting.

"To whomever finds this," it read, "know that the true treasure is knowledge and the preservation of history. Do not let greed or superstition cloud your judgment."

Holmes looked up, a satisfied smile on his face. "The mystery is solved, and the truth revealed."

We left the estate as dawn broke, the building standing silent and imposing once more.

As we walked away, Holmes reflected, "Every place has its story, and every story has its truth. It is our task to uncover it, no matter how deep or hidden it may be."

And so, the case of the haunted estate was closed, leaving behind only the whispers of the past and the enduring legacy of discovery.

events.title: The Plan, Vigil Preparations, and Holmes's Deductions
detailed_summary: Holmes stresses the absolute importance of Helen following his instructions precisely, as her life depends on it.
He informs Helen and Watson that he and Watson must spend the night in her current bedroom.
He points out the village inn (The Crown) from which her window is visible.
He instructs Helen to feign a headache upon Roylott's return, wait until he retires, then open her window shutters and place her lamp as a signal.
She must then quietly move to her original room for the night.
Holmes assures her they will handle the rest and investigate the noise.
Helen senses Holmes has solved the case and pleads to know Julia's cause of death.
Holmes prefers clearer proof before speaking but dismisses her theory of death by fright, suggesting a more tangible cause.
They leave quickly to avoid Roylott's return.
Holmes and Watson secure rooms at The Crown Inn with a view of the manor.
They observe Dr. Roylott's return at dusk, noting his menacing behaviour towards the boy driving the trap.
As darkness falls, Holmes expresses concerns about the danger Watson faces that night, but Watson insists on coming.

Holmes explains his deductions: the cigar smell implied a connection between rooms, leading him to expect the ventilator; its installation coinciding with the dummy bell-rope and Julia's death is suspicious.
He points out the bed is clamped to the floor, always positioned relative to the ventilator and the rope (intended as a bridge, not a bell-pull).
Watson begins to understand the horrific implications.
Holmes remarks on the danger of a criminal doctor with nerve and knowledge, suggesting they await the night's horrors after a calming pipe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had never seen my friend’s face so grim or his brow so dark as it was when we turned from the scene of this investigation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But we shall have horrors enough before the night is over; for goodness’ sake let us have a quiet pipe and turn our minds for a few hours to something more cheerful.”

events.text_segment:
I had never seen my friend’s face so grim or his brow so dark as it was when we turned from the scene of this investigation. We had walked several times up and down the lawn, neither Miss Stoner nor myself liking to break in upon his thoughts before he roused himself from his reverie.
“It is very essential, Miss Stoner,” said he, “that you should absolutely follow my advice in every respect.”
“I shall most certainly do so.”
“The matter is too serious for any hesitation. Your life may depend upon your compliance.”
“I assure you that I am in your hands.”
“In the first place, both my friend and I must spend the night in your room.”
Both Miss Stoner and I gazed at him in astonishment.
“Yes, it must be so. Let me explain. I believe that that is the village inn over there?”
“Yes, that is the Crown.”
“Very good. Your windows would be visible from there?”
“Certainly.”
“You must confine yourself to your room, on pretence of a headache, when your stepfather comes back. Then when you hear him retire for the night, you must open the shutters of your window, undo the hasp, put your lamp there as a signal to us, and then withdraw quietly with everything which you are likely to want into the room which you used to occupy. I have no doubt that, in spite of the repairs, you could manage there for one night.”
“Oh, yes, easily.”
“The rest you will leave in our hands.”
“But what will you do?”
“We shall spend the night in your room, and we shall investigate the cause of this noise which has disturbed you.”
“I believe, Mr. Holmes, that you have already made up your mind,” said Miss Stoner, laying her hand upon my companion’s sleeve.
“Perhaps I have.”
“Then, for pity’s sake, tell me what was the cause of my sister’s death.”
“I should prefer to have clearer proofs before I speak.”
“You can at least tell me whether my own thought is correct, and if she died from some sudden fright.”
“No, I do not think so. I think that there was probably some more tangible cause. And now, Miss Stoner, we must leave you for if Dr. Roylott returned and saw us our journey would be in vain. Good-bye, and be brave, for if you will do what I have told you, you may rest assured that we shall soon drive away the dangers that threaten you.”
Sherlock Holmes and I had no difficulty in engaging a bedroom and sitting-room at the Crown Inn. They were on the upper floor, and from our window we could command a view of the avenue gate, and of the inhabited wing of Stoke Moran Manor House. At dusk we saw Dr. Grimesby Roylott drive past, his huge form looming up beside the little figure of the lad who drove him. The boy had some slight difficulty in undoing the heavy iron gates, and we heard the hoarse roar of the Doctor’s voice and saw the fury with which he shook his clinched fists at him. The trap drove on, and a few minutes later we saw a sudden light spring up among the trees as the lamp was lit in one of the sitting-rooms.
“Do you know, Watson,” said Holmes as we sat together in the gathering darkness, “I have really some scruples as to taking you to-night. There is a distinct element of danger.”
“Can I be of assistance?”
“Your presence might be invaluable.”
“Then I shall certainly come.”
“It is very kind of you.”
“You speak of danger. You have evidently seen more in these rooms than was visible to me.”
“No, but I fancy that I may have deduced a little more. I imagine that you saw all that I did.”
“I saw nothing remarkable save the bell-rope, and what purpose that could answer I confess is more than I can imagine.”
“You saw the ventilator, too?”
“Yes, but I do not think that it is such a very unusual thing to have a small opening between two rooms. It was so small that a rat could hardly pass through.”
“I knew that we should find a ventilator before ever we came to Stoke Moran.”
“My dear Holmes!”
“Oh, yes, I did. You remember in her statement she said that her sister could smell Dr. Roylott’s cigar. Now, of course that suggested at once that there must be a communication between the two rooms. It could only be a small one, or it would have been remarked upon at the coroner’s inquiry. I deduced a ventilator.”
“But what harm can there be in that?”
“Well, there is at least a curious coincidence of dates. A ventilator is made, a cord is hung, and a lady who sleeps in the bed dies. Does not that strike you?”
“I cannot as yet see any connection.”
“Did you observe anything very peculiar about that bed?”
“No.”
“It was clamped to the floor. Did you ever see a bed fastened like that before?”
“I cannot say that I have.”
“The lady could not move her bed. It must always be in the same relative position to the ventilator and to the rope—or so we may call it, since it was clearly never meant for a bell-pull.”
“Holmes,” I cried, “I seem to see dimly what you are hinting at. We are only just in time to prevent some subtle and horrible crime.”
“Subtle enough and horrible enough. When a doctor does go wrong he is the first of criminals. He has nerve and he has knowledge. Palmer and Pritchard were among the heads of their profession. This man strikes even deeper, but I think, Watson, that we shall be able to strike deeper still. But we shall have horrors enough before the night is over; for goodness’ sake let us have a quiet pipe and turn our minds for a few hours to something more cheerful.”

**"I had never seen my friend’s face so grim or his brow so dark as it was when we turned from the scene of this investigation."**

Holmes’s expression was grim, his brow heavy with concern. He turned to Helen Stoner, who was trembling with anxiety. “Miss Stoner,” he said firmly, “you must follow my instructions precisely tonight. Your life depends on it.”

He explained that he and Watson would spend the night in her room, and that she should feign a headache when Roylott returned. Once he retired, she was to open her window shutters, light her lamp as a signal, and then quietly move back to her original room for the night. Holmes emphasized that she must not make any noise or draw attention.

Helen looked at him with wide eyes. “And if he sees me?” she asked.

“Remain calm,” Holmes replied. “The signal will be your cue. When you see the lamp, you will know the moment to act. We will be watching from the next room.”

Watson nodded in agreement, and Holmes added, “Remember, the ventilator, the dummy bell-rope, and the bed are all part of the trap. Stay alert.”

They quickly arranged to stay at The Crown Inn, which had a good view of the estate. As dusk fell, they observed Roylott returning home, his menacing figure looming in the fading light. Holmes noted his suspicious behavior—his quick, deliberate movements and the way he glared at the house.

Holmes then turned to Watson and said quietly, “The cigar smell in the room suggests a connection between the ventilator and the dummy bell-rope. The bed is clamped to the floor, always positioned relative to the ventilator and the rope, which is intended as a bridge, not a bell-pull. Julia’s death was no accident; it was murder.”

As night approached, Holmes expressed concern about Watson’s safety, but Watson insisted on staying. Holmes, with a calm but serious tone, explained his deductions: the ventilator was meant to serve as a conduit for the deadly creature, and the dummy bell-rope was a distraction. The real danger was Roylott’s plan to use the snake to kill Miss Stoner.

Holmes then suggested they wait patiently, lighting his pipe and preparing for the night’s events. “Tonight,” he said softly, “we shall uncover the truth and put an end to this terrible scheme.”

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The shadows of the evening stretched long across the quiet street, and a chill wind seemed to carry with it the whispers of secrets long kept. Holmes, ever the keen observer, examined the surroundings with a meticulous eye, his brow furrowed in thought. 'This case,' he murmured, 'is far from ordinary. The clues point to a most intricate web of deception.' I watched him closely, noting the rare seriousness that had overtaken his usual composed demeanor.

As we made our way back to Baker Street, Holmes was silent for a moment, lost in thought. Then he turned to me, his eyes gleaming with a mixture of excitement and concern. 'Watson,' he said, 'we are on the brink of uncovering a matter that could have serious repercussions. The victim was not merely a man of business, but someone entangled in affairs far more complex than they appeared.'

The next morning, Holmes was already deep in his research, pouring over documents and correspondence related to the case. I observed him as he pieced together the fragments of information, his mind working at a pace that seemed almost supernatural. Suddenly, he looked up, a spark of revelation in his eyes.

'Watson,' he exclaimed, 'I believe I have it. The motive is rooted in a long-standing feud, and the key to solving this lies in the old records of the local guild.' Without delay, Holmes gathered his papers and set out to the archives, leaving me to prepare for what promised to be a revealing afternoon.

By the time Holmes returned, he was triumphant. 'The puzzle is solved,' he announced. 'Our victim was involved in a dispute over a valuable inheritance, and the perpetrator sought to conceal their involvement through a series of elaborate deceptions.' As he explained, I could see the satisfaction in his expression, tempered by the gravity of the crime uncovered.

Holmes then outlined the steps we would take to bring the culprit to justice, emphasizing the importance of discretion and precision. We prepared our case meticulously, ensuring that every detail was accounted for. The following days were filled with careful surveillance and gathering of evidence, all leading to a climactic confrontation.

Finally, the day arrived when Holmes and I confronted the suspect, who was none other than a trusted associate of the victim, driven by greed and desperation. The confession was as swift as it was damning, and justice was duly served. As we left the scene, Holmes reflected on the case.

'Watson,' he said, 'this case reminds us that beneath the veneer of civility, human nature can harbor dark secrets. It is our duty to uncover them, no matter how deeply they are buried.' I nodded, grateful for the opportunity to assist in such a pursuit of truth.

That evening, as we sat in our rooms, Holmes resumed his usual demeanor, a faint smile playing on his lips. 'Another case closed,' he mused, 'but many more await us. The game is afoot, as always.' I could not help but feel a renewed sense of purpose, inspired by Holmes's unwavering dedication to justice and the pursuit of knowledge.

events.text_segment:
About nine o’clock the light among the trees was extinguished, and all was dark in the direction of the Manor House. Two hours passed slowly away, and then, suddenly, just at the stroke of eleven, a single bright light shone out right in front of us.
“That is our signal,” said Holmes, springing to his feet; “it comes from the middle window.”
As we passed out he exchanged a few words with the landlord, explaining that we were going on a late visit to an acquaintance, and that it was possible that we might spend the night there. A moment later we were out on the dark road, a chill wind blowing in our faces, and one yellow light twinkling in front of us through the gloom to guide us on our sombre errand.
There was little difficulty in entering the grounds, for unrepaired breaches gaped in the old park wall. Making our way among the trees, we reached the lawn, crossed it, and were about to enter through the window when out from a clump of laurel bushes there darted what seemed to be a hideous and distorted child, who threw itself upon the grass with writhing limbs and then ran swiftly across the lawn into the darkness.
“My God!” I whispered; “did you see it?”
Holmes was for the moment as startled as I. His hand closed like a vice upon my wrist in his agitation. Then he broke into a low laugh and put his lips to my ear.
“It is a nice household,” he murmured. “That is the baboon.”
I had forgotten the strange pets which the Doctor affected. There was a cheetah, too; perhaps we might find it upon our shoulders at any moment. I confess that I felt easier in my mind when, after following Holmes’ example and slipping off my shoes, I found myself inside the bedroom. My companion noiselessly closed the shutters, moved the lamp onto the table, and cast his eyes round the room. All was as we had seen it in the daytime. Then creeping up to me and making a trumpet of his hand, he whispered into my ear again so gently that it was all that I could do to distinguish the words:
“The least sound would be fatal to our plans.”
I nodded to show that I had heard.
“We must sit without light. He would see it through the ventilator.”
I nodded again.
“Do not go asleep; your very life may depend upon it. Have your pistol ready in case we should need it. I will sit on the side of the bed, and you in that chair.”
I took out my revolver and laid it on the corner of the table.
Holmes had brought up a long thin cane, and this he placed upon the bed beside him. By it he laid the box of matches and the stump of a candle. Then he turned down the lamp, and we were left in darkness.
How shall I ever forget that dreadful vigil? I could not hear a sound, not even the drawing of a breath, and yet I knew that my companion sat open-eyed, within a few feet of me, in the same state of nervous tension in which I was myself. The shutters cut off the least ray of light, and we waited in absolute darkness.
From outside came the occasional cry of a night-bird, and once at our very window a long drawn catlike whine, which told us that the cheetah was indeed at liberty. Far away we could hear the deep tones of the parish clock, which boomed out every quarter of an hour. How long they seemed, those quarters! Twelve struck, and one and two and three, and still we sat waiting silently for whatever might befall.
Suddenly there was the momentary gleam of a light up in the direction of the ventilator, which vanished immediately, but was succeeded by a strong smell of burning oil and heated metal. Someone in the next room had lit a dark-lantern. I heard a gentle sound of movement, and then all was silent once more, though the smell grew stronger. For half an hour I sat with straining ears. Then suddenly another sound became audible—a very gentle, soothing sound, like that of a small jet of steam escaping continually from a kettle. The instant that we heard it, Holmes sprang from the bed, struck a match, and lashed furiously with his cane at the bell-pull.
“You see it, Watson?” he yelled. “You see it?”
But I saw nothing. At the moment when Holmes struck the light I heard a low, clear whistle, but the sudden glare flashing into my weary eyes made it impossible for me to tell what it was at which my friend lashed so savagely. I could, however, see that his face was deadly pale and filled with horror and loathing. He had ceased to strike and was gazing up at the ventilator when suddenly there broke from the silence of the night the most horrible cry to which I have ever listened. It swelled up louder and louder, a hoarse yell of pain and fear and anger all mingled in the one dreadful shriek. They say that away down in the village, and even in the distant parsonage, that cry raised the sleepers from their beds. It struck cold to our hearts, and I stood gazing at Holmes, and he at me, until the last echoes of it had died away into the silence from which it rose.
“What can it mean?” I gasped.
“It means that it is all over,” Holmes answered. “And perhaps, after all, it is for the best. Take your pistol, and we will enter Dr. Roylott’s room.”
With a grave face he lit the lamp and led the way down the corridor. Twice he struck at the chamber door without any reply from within. Then he turned the handle and entered, I at his heels, with the cocked pistol in my hand.
It was a singular sight which met our eyes. On the table stood a dark-lantern with the shutter half open, throwing a brilliant beam of light upon the iron safe, the door of which was ajar. Beside this table, on the wooden chair, sat Dr. Grimesby Roylott clad in a long grey dressing-gown, his bare ankles protruding beneath, and his feet thrust into red heelless Turkish slippers. Across his lap lay the short stock with the long lash which we had noticed during the day. His chin was cocked upward and his eyes were fixed in a dreadful, rigid stare at the corner of the ceiling. Round his brow he had a peculiar yellow band, with brownish speckles, which seemed to be bound tightly round his head. As we entered he made neither sound nor motion.
“The band! the speckled band!” whispered Holmes.
I took a step forward. In an instant his strange headgear began to move, and there reared itself from among his hair the squat diamond-shaped head and puffed neck of a loathsome serpent.
“It is a swamp adder!” cried Holmes; “the deadliest snake in India. He has died within ten seconds of being bitten. Violence does, in truth, recoil upon the violent, and the schemer falls into the pit which he digs for another. Let us thrust this creature back into its den, and we can then remove Miss Stoner to some place of shelter and let the county police know what has happened.”
As he spoke he drew the dog-whip swiftly from the dead man’s lap, and throwing the noose round the reptile’s neck he drew it from its horrid perch and, carrying it at arm’s length, threw it into the iron safe, which he closed upon it.
Such are the true facts of the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott, of Stoke Moran. It is not necessary that I should prolong a narrative which has already run to too great a length by telling how we broke the sad news to the terrified girl, how we conveyed her by the morning train to the care of her good aunt at Harrow, of how the slow process of official inquiry came to the conclusion that the doctor met his fate while indiscreetly playing with a dangerous pet. The little which I had yet to learn of the case was told me by Sherlock Holmes as we travelled back next day.
“I had,” said he, “come to an entirely erroneous conclusion which shows, my dear Watson, how dangerous it always is to reason from insufficient data. The presence of the gipsies, and the use of the word ‘band,’ which was used by the poor girl, no doubt, to explain the appearance which she had caught a hurried glimpse of by the light of her match, were sufficient to put me upon an entirely wrong scent. I can only claim the merit that I instantly reconsidered my position when, however, it became clear to me that whatever danger threatened an occupant of the room could not come either from the window or the door. My attention was speedily drawn, as I have already remarked to you, to this ventilator, and to the bell-rope which hung down to the bed. The discovery that this was a dummy, and that the bed was clamped to the floor, instantly gave rise to the suspicion that the rope was there as a bridge for something passing through the hole and coming to the bed. The idea of a snake instantly occurred to me, and when I coupled it with my knowledge that the doctor was furnished with a supply of creatures from India, I felt that I was probably on the right track. The idea of using a form of poison which could not possibly be discovered by any chemical test was just such a one as would occur to a clever and ruthless man who had had an Eastern training. The rapidity with which such a poison would take effect would also, from his point of view, be an advantage. It would be a sharp-eyed coroner, indeed, who could distinguish the two little dark punctures which would show where the poison fangs had done their work. Then I thought of the whistle. Of course he must recall the snake before the morning light revealed it to the victim. He had trained it, probably by the use of the milk which we saw, to return to him when summoned. He would put it through this ventilator at the hour that he thought best, with the certainty that it would crawl down the rope and land on the bed. It might or might not bite the occupant, perhaps she might escape every night for a week, but sooner or later she must fall a victim.
“I had come to these conclusions before ever I had entered his room. An inspection of his chair showed me that he had been in the habit of standing on it, which of course would be necessary in order that he should reach the ventilator. The sight of the safe, the saucer of milk, and the loop of whipcord were enough to finally dispel any doubts which may have remained. The metallic clang heard by Miss Stoner was obviously caused by her stepfather hastily closing the door of his safe upon its terrible occupant. Having once made up my mind, you know the steps which I took in order to put the matter to the proof. I heard the creature hiss as I have no doubt that you did also, and I instantly lit the light and attacked it.”
“With the result of driving it through the ventilator.”
“And also with the result of causing it to turn upon its master at the other side. Some of the blows of my cane came home and roused its snakish temper, so that it flew upon the first person it saw. In this way I am no doubt indirectly responsible for Dr. Grimesby Roylott’s death, and I cannot say that it is likely to weigh very heavily upon my conscience.”

Inside, they found Roylott seated dead in his chair, beside an open safe illuminated by a dark-lantern. A peculiar speckled yellow band was tight around his head. Holmes whispered, "The band! the speckled band!" As Watson stepped forward, the band moved, revealing the head of a snake. Holmes identified it as a deadly swamp adder, stating Roylott died seconds after being bitten.

He reflected that violence recoils on the violent. Using the dog-whip from Roylott’s lap, Holmes noosed the snake and threw it into the iron safe, closing it. Watson concludes the main narrative here, stating these are the true facts of Roylott’s death. He briefly mentions informing Helen, taking her to her aunt, and the official verdict of accidental death from a pet.

On the return journey, Holmes explains his reasoning. He admits initially suspecting the gipsies due to the band reference. Realizing entry via window or door was impossible, he refocused his attention on the ventilator and dummy bell-rope. The clamped bed confirmed the rope was a bridge. The idea of a snake, coupled with Roylott’s Indian connections and the need for an undetectable poison, solidified the theory. The whistle was to recall the snake.

Inspection of Roylott’s chair (showing he stood on it), the safe, milk, and whipcord loop confirmed his suspicions. The metallic clang was the safe door closing. Holmes confirms his attack with the cane drove the agitated snake back through the ventilator, causing it to fatally attack Roylott. Holmes feels no guilt over his indirect role in Roylott’s death.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The night had fallen swiftly, cloaking the landscape in a shroud of shadows. The only sounds were the rustling of leaves and the distant hoot of an owl, creating an atmosphere thick with anticipation and mystery. Sherlock Holmes, seated in his armchair by the fireplace, was lost in thought, his keen eyes reflecting the flickering flames. Dr. Watson, ever the attentive companion, watched him with a mixture of curiosity and concern.

Suddenly, a faint noise interrupted the silence—a soft, almost imperceptible creak coming from the direction of the manor. Holmes sat upright, his senses sharpened. He reached for his violin, not to play, but to listen more intently. The sound was repeated, this time more distinctly, as if someone was moving cautiously through the underbrush.

"Watson," Holmes whispered, "there is something afoot at the manor tonight. I suspect that the darkness has emboldened some intruder or perhaps a thief. We must investigate."

Without delay, Holmes grabbed his coat and deerstalker hat, and the two of them set out into the night. The air was crisp, and the moon cast a pale glow over the landscape, illuminating the path that led toward the manor. As they approached, they could see faint footprints in the soft earth—deliberate, cautious steps that suggested someone was trying to avoid detection.

Holmes knelt down, examining the footprints carefully. "These are recent," he murmured. "A single set, leading from the woods to the back entrance. Whoever it is, they are skilled at remaining unseen."

They moved closer, staying in the shadows, until they reached the rear of the manor. Holmes signaled for Watson to stay back while he crept forward, peering through a window. Inside, he saw a figure rummaging through a cabinet, a faint glint of a stolen object in their hand.

"We must act swiftly," Holmes whispered. He signaled to Watson, who nodded and prepared to assist. Holmes then quietly entered through a side door, which was slightly ajar. Inside, the intruder was startled, turning sharply as Holmes stepped into the room.

"Good evening," Holmes said calmly. "I believe you are trespassing."

The intruder, a young man with a nervous demeanor, hesitated before speaking. "I... I didn't mean any harm. I was just looking for something to help my family."

Holmes studied him intently. "Stealing from the manor is not the answer. Tell me your story."

The young man explained that he was desperate, that his family was starving, and he had heard that the manor's owner kept valuable items in the house. Holmes listened patiently, then made a decision.

"Come with me," he said gently. "We will see what can be done to help your family, but theft is not the way."

They exited the house together, Holmes guiding the young man away from the scene. As they walked back toward their lodgings, Holmes reflected on the night's events.

"Watson," he said, "this case reminds us that even in the darkest of nights, there is often a human story behind the crime. Our role is to uncover the truth and seek justice, not merely to catch the wrongdoer."

Back at their rooms, Holmes penned a note to the local authorities, explaining the situation and the young man's circumstances. He also arranged for aid to be provided to the young man's family.

The dawn was breaking as they returned to their respective pursuits, the mystery of the night resolved with compassion and understanding. Holmes's keen mind had once again unraveled a complex situation, revealing that sometimes, the most intricate cases are those that touch the heart.

chapters.chapter_title: IX. THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER’S THUMB

events.title: Watson Introduces the Case of the Engineer's Thumb
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson reflects on the cases he brought to Sherlock Holmes, highlighting the peculiar and dramatic nature of Mr. Hatherley's thumb case over Colonel Warburton's madness.
He notes that while the latter might have offered more scope for Holmes's observational skills, the Hatherley case is more memorable due to its strange beginnings and dramatic unfolding.
Watson mentions that the story appeared in newspapers but argues its impact is greater when experienced step-by-step rather than as a brief summary.
He states the events left a lasting impression on him over the past two years.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Of all the problems which have been submitted to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, for solution during the years of our intimacy, there were only two which I was the means of introducing to his notice—that of Mr. Hatherley’s thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton’s madness.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At the time the circumstances made a deep impression upon me, and the lapse of two years has hardly served to weaken the effect.

events.text_segment: Of all the problems which have been submitted to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, for solution during the years of our intimacy, there were only two which I was the means of introducing to his notice—that of Mr. Hatherley’s thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton’s madness. Of these the latter may have afforded a finer field for an acute and original observer, but the other was so strange in its inception and so dramatic in its details that it may be the more worthy of being placed upon record, even if it gave my friend fewer openings for those deductive methods of reasoning by which he achieved such remarkable results. The story has, I believe, been told more than once in the newspapers, but, like all such narratives, its effect is much less striking when set forth en bloc in a single half-column of print than when the facts slowly evolve before your own eyes, and the mystery clears gradually away as each new discovery furnishes a step which leads on to the complete truth. At the time the circumstances made a deep impression upon me, and the lapse of two years has hardly served to weaken the effect.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Of all the problems which have been submitted to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, for solution during the years of our intimacy, there were only two which I was the means of introducing to his notice—that of Mr. Hatherley’s thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton’s madness. The first was a strange and dramatic affair, which I have often thought of since, and the second was a case that might have been more interesting to a less observant man than Holmes, but which I confess I found less memorable. The story of Mr. Hatherley's thumb, with its peculiar circumstances and startling developments, made a deep impression on me, and I remember it well, even after the lapse of two years. It was a case that appeared in the newspapers, but I believe its true significance is only appreciated when one considers the details step by step, rather than in a brief summary. Holmes himself was quite intrigued by the case, and I recall how he examined the evidence with his usual keen eye, unraveling the mystery behind the strange injury and the bizarre events that followed.

events.title: An Early Morning Summons and a Distressed Patient
detailed_summary: Watson recounts the time of the event: summer 1889, shortly after his marriage, having returned to civil practice but maintaining contact with Holmes.
His proximity to Paddington Station brought him railway-related patients, one of whom, a grateful guard, actively recommended his services.
One morning before 7 am, Watson is awakened by his maid reporting two men from Paddington waiting in his consulting-room.
He dresses quickly, anticipating a serious railway case, and finds the friendly guard downstairs.
The guard whispers conspiratorially that he has brought a 'new patient' and ensured he wouldn't leave, before departing for his duties.
Watson enters to find a pale, agitated young man, dressed in tweed, with a blood-soaked handkerchief wrapped around one hand.
The man introduces himself apologetically as Victor Hatherley, a hydraulic engineer, explaining he suffered a serious accident and was directed to Watson at Paddington.
Watson reads his card: 'Mr. Victor Hatherley, hydraulic engineer, 16A, Victoria Street (3rd floor)'.
When Watson comments on the monotony of a night journey, Hatherley bursts into uncontrollable, hearty laughter, unsettling Watson's medical senses.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was in the summer of ’89, not long after my marriage, that the events occurred which I am now about to summarise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All my medical instincts rose up against that laugh.

events.text_segment:
It was in the summer of ’89, not long after my marriage, that the events occurred which I am now about to summarise. I had returned to civil practice and had finally abandoned Holmes in his Baker Street rooms, although I continually visited him and occasionally even persuaded him to forgo his Bohemian habits so far as to come and visit us. My practice had steadily increased, and as I happened to live at no very great distance from Paddington Station, I got a few patients from among the officials. One of these, whom I had cured of a painful and lingering disease, was never weary of advertising my virtues and of endeavouring to send me on every sufferer over whom he might have any influence.
One morning, at a little before seven o’clock, I was awakened by the maid tapping at the door to announce that two men had come from Paddington and were waiting in the consulting-room. I dressed hurriedly, for I knew by experience that railway cases were seldom trivial, and hastened downstairs. As I descended, my old ally, the guard, came out of the room and closed the door tightly behind him.
“I’ve got him here,” he whispered, jerking his thumb over his shoulder; “he’s all right.”
“What is it, then?” I asked, for his manner suggested that it was some strange creature which he had caged up in my room.
“It’s a new patient,” he whispered. “I thought I’d bring him round myself; then he couldn’t slip away. There he is, all safe and sound. I must go now, Doctor; I have my dooties, just the same as you.” And off he went, this trusty tout, without even giving me time to thank him.
I entered my consulting-room and found a gentleman seated by the table. He was quietly dressed in a suit of heather tweed with a soft cloth cap which he had laid down upon my books. Round one of his hands he had a handkerchief wrapped, which was mottled all over with bloodstains. He was young, not more than five-and-twenty, I should say, with a strong, masculine face; but he was exceedingly pale and gave me the impression of a man who was suffering from some strong agitation, which it took all his strength of mind to control.
“I am sorry to knock you up so early, Doctor,” said he, “but I have had a very serious accident during the night. I came in by train this morning, and on inquiring at Paddington as to where I might find a doctor, a worthy fellow very kindly escorted me here. I gave the maid a card, but I see that she has left it upon the side-table.”
I took it up and glanced at it. “Mr. Victor Hatherley, hydraulic engineer, 16A, Victoria Street (3rd floor).” That was the name, style, and abode of my morning visitor. “I regret that I have kept you waiting,” said I, sitting down in my library-chair. “You are fresh from a night journey, I understand, which is in itself a monotonous occupation.”
“Oh, my night could not be called monotonous,” said he, and laughed. He laughed very heartily, with a high, ringing note, leaning back in his chair and shaking his sides. All my medical instincts rose up against that laugh.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was in the summer of ’89, not long after my marriage, that the events occurred which I am now about to summarise. I remember it vividly, for it was a case that tested even Sherlock Holmes’s remarkable powers of deduction. The day had begun like any other, with Holmes and myself sitting in our Baker Street apartment, when a hurried knock at the door interrupted our quiet morning.

A tall, anxious-looking man entered, introducing himself as Mr. James McCarthy, a solicitor from the city. He carried with him a letter, which he handed to Holmes. The letter was from a client of his, a Mrs. Eleanor Gray, who was in a state of distress. She claimed that her valuable family heirloom, a diamond necklace, had been stolen from her residence.

Holmes listened intently, his keen eyes narrowing as he examined the letter. He then asked Mr. McCarthy for more details. Mrs. Gray’s house was a grand estate on the outskirts of London, and she had last seen the necklace the previous evening. When she awoke this morning, it was gone. The house had been locked and secured, and no signs of forced entry were evident.

Holmes decided to visit the scene of the crime immediately. We set out at once, accompanied by Mr. McCarthy. Upon arriving, Holmes carefully inspected the room where the necklace was kept. He noted the position of the furniture, the lock on the cabinet, and the arrangement of the room. His sharp gaze caught a faint smudge on the window latch.

Back in Baker Street, Holmes pondered the clues. He deduced that the thief was someone familiar with the household, perhaps a servant or someone who had access. He questioned the staff, but they all claimed to have been elsewhere at the time of the theft.

Holmes then turned his attention to the household staff. He observed that the butler, Mr. Collins, seemed unusually nervous. Holmes’s intuition told him that the answer lay in the servant’s quarters. That evening, Holmes and I visited the estate again, this time to speak with the staff.

Holmes’s keen eye noticed a small, torn piece of fabric caught on a nail near the servant’s door. It matched the uniform of the butler. Confronted with this evidence, Mr. Collins broke down and confessed. He had stolen the necklace to pay off debts, planning to return it after a quick sale.

The necklace was recovered from Collins’s room, hidden behind a loose panel. Mrs. Gray was overjoyed to have her heirloom returned, and Holmes’s reputation was once again confirmed. This case exemplified his extraordinary deductive skills and his ability to see what others overlooked.

As I reflect on that summer day, I am reminded of the importance of keen observation and logical reasoning. Holmes’s methods, though sometimes unorthodox, always led to the truth. It was a lesson I have carried with me ever since, and one that has served me well in many a subsequent adventure.

events.title: Revealing the Gruesome Injury
detailed_summary: Watson attempts to calm Hatherley, recognizing his hysterical laughter as a reaction to a severe crisis.
Hatherley recovers, feeling foolish, and Watson gives him brandy-laced water, restoring some colour to his face.
Hatherley then asks Watson to attend to his hand, revealing the place 'where my thumb used to be'.
He unwraps the handkerchief, exposing a horrific wound: the thumb is gone, completely hacked or torn out, leaving a red, spongy surface.
Watson is shocked by the terrible injury and notes it must have bled significantly.
Hatherley confirms he fainted after the injury and, upon waking, used his handkerchief and a twig as a makeshift tourniquet.
Watson commends his resourcefulness, which Hatherley attributes to his hydraulics knowledge.
Examining the wound, Watson determines it was caused by a heavy, sharp instrument, like a cleaver, according to Hatherley.
Hatherley confirms it was not an accident but a 'very murderous' attack, horrifying Watson.
Watson cleans and dresses the severe wound while Hatherley endures the process stoically.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Stop it!” I cried; “pull yourself together!” and I poured out some water from a caraffe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He lay back without wincing, though he bit his lip from time to time.

events.text_segment:
“Stop it!” I cried; “pull yourself together!” and I poured out some water from a caraffe.
It was useless, however. He was off in one of those hysterical outbursts which come upon a strong nature when some great crisis is over and gone. Presently he came to himself once more, very weary and pale-looking.
“I have been making a fool of myself,” he gasped.
“Not at all. Drink this.” I dashed some brandy into the water, and the colour began to come back to his bloodless cheeks.
“That’s better!” said he. “And now, Doctor, perhaps you would kindly attend to my thumb, or rather to the place where my thumb used to be.”
He unwound the handkerchief and held out his hand. It gave even my hardened nerves a shudder to look at it. There were four protruding fingers and a horrid red, spongy surface where the thumb should have been. It had been hacked or torn right out from the roots.
“Good heavens!” I cried, “this is a terrible injury. It must have bled considerably.”
“Yes, it did. I fainted when it was done, and I think that I must have been senseless for a long time. When I came to I found that it was still bleeding, so I tied one end of my handkerchief very tightly round the wrist and braced it up with a twig.”
“Excellent! You should have been a surgeon.”
“It is a question of hydraulics, you see, and came within my own province.”
“This has been done,” said I, examining the wound, “by a very heavy and sharp instrument.”
“A thing like a cleaver,” said he.
“An accident, I presume?”
“By no means.”
“What! a murderous attack?”
“Very murderous indeed.”
“You horrify me.”
I sponged the wound, cleaned it, dressed it, and finally covered it over with cotton wadding and carbolised bandages. He lay back without wincing, though he bit his lip from time to time.

The man before me was trembling violently, his face pale and streaked with sweat. As I handed him the glass of water, he took it with trembling hands and drank greedily, the cool liquid soothing his parched throat. After a moment, he looked up at me with a mixture of fear and relief. "Thank you," he whispered hoarsely. "I... I didn't mean to cause such a scene. It's just that I saw something—something terrible."

I studied him carefully, noting the beads of sweat on his brow and the haunted look in his eyes. "Calm yourself," I said gently. "Tell me what you saw. Perhaps I can help."

He hesitated, then took a deep breath and began to speak. "I was walking past the old mill at the edge of the village when I saw a shadow moving inside. At first, I thought it was just a trick of the light, but then I saw a figure—someone hiding behind the broken machinery. I called out, but they didn't answer. I was about to go closer when I heard a noise—like a struggle."

His hands trembled as he recounted the scene. "I saw a man, or perhaps a woman, struggling with another person. Then, suddenly, they disappeared from view. I was so frightened I ran here as fast as I could."

I nodded thoughtfully, considering his story. "This is quite serious. We must investigate further. Did you notice anything else—any clues, or perhaps a weapon?"

He shook his head. "No, I didn't see anything else. But I know what I saw, and I believe it was something criminal."

I placed a reassuring hand on his shoulder. "Stay here for a moment. I will look into this matter immediately. Rest assured, we will get to the bottom of it."

events.title: Seeking Sherlock Holmes's Expertise
detailed_summary: After Watson finishes bandaging the wound, Hatherley feels much better, attributing it to the brandy and the bandage.
Watson advises him not to talk about the incident yet, but Hatherley insists, needing to tell the police.
Hatherley expresses doubt that the police will believe his extraordinary story due to lack of proof and vague clues, questioning if justice can be served.
Recognizing a complex problem, Watson strongly recommends consulting his friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, before approaching the official police.
Hatherley has heard of Holmes and is eager for his help, though still intending to involve the police, and asks for an introduction.
Watson offers to take him directly to Baker Street himself.
Hatherley gratefully accepts, feeling unable to rest until he tells his story.

events.text_segment:
“How is that?” I asked when I had finished.
“Capital! Between your brandy and your bandage, I feel a new man. I was very weak, but I have had a good deal to go through.”
“Perhaps you had better not speak of the matter. It is evidently trying to your nerves.”
“Oh, no, not now. I shall have to tell my tale to the police; but, between ourselves, if it were not for the convincing evidence of this wound of mine, I should be surprised if they believed my statement, for it is a very extraordinary one, and I have not much in the way of proof with which to back it up; and, even if they believe me, the clues which I can give them are so vague that it is a question whether justice will be done.”
“Ha!” cried I, “if it is anything in the nature of a problem which you desire to see solved, I should strongly recommend you to come to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, before you go to the official police.”
“Oh, I have heard of that fellow,” answered my visitor, “and I should be very glad if he would take the matter up, though of course I must use the official police as well. Would you give me an introduction to him?”
“I’ll do better. I’ll take you round to him myself.”
“I should be immensely obliged to you.”
“We’ll call a cab and go together. We shall just be in time to have a little breakfast with him. Do you feel equal to it?”
“Yes; I shall not feel easy until I have told my story.”
“Then my servant will call a cab, and I shall be with you in an instant.” I rushed upstairs, explained the matter shortly to my wife, and in five minutes was inside a hansom, driving with my new acquaintance to Baker Street.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"How is that?" I asked when I had finished.

Hatherley looked at his hand and then at me, a faint smile flickering across his face.

"Much better, thank you," he said. "The brandy and the bandage seem to have done their work."

I nodded, feeling a sense of relief that he was recovering.

"You must not talk about this just yet," I advised. "It’s best to keep it quiet until we know more."

He shook his head earnestly. "No, I can't keep silent. I need to tell the police. They must know what’s happened."

"But your story is so extraordinary," I pointed out. "The police might find it hard to believe without proof."

He looked uncertain. "That’s what worries me. I don’t see how justice can be served without some evidence."

Recognizing the complexity of the situation, I urged caution. "You should see Holmes before you go to the police. He’s the best man to advise you."

Hatherley’s eyes lit up. "I’ve heard of Mr. Holmes. I’d be grateful for his help. Could you introduce me?"

"Certainly," I said. "I’ll take you to Baker Street myself."

He hesitated only a moment before nodding. "Thank you. I can’t rest until I’ve told someone."

I arranged for a cab outside, briefly informed my wife of our plans, and we set off for Baker Street in a hansom, the city rushing past us as I pondered the strange and troubling story that awaited Holmes.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Holmes leaned back in his chair, a contemplative look on his face. "It is quite a clever deduction," he said slowly. "The way you observed the faint smudge on the windowpane, combined with the pattern of footprints outside, reveals that the intruder was a tall man, wearing a heavy coat, and that he entered through the back door around midnight. The broken lock indicates a hurried entry, perhaps driven by desperation or urgency."

I nodded, impressed by his keen eye. "And the missing letter?"

"Ah, yes," Holmes replied, his eyes twinkling. "The letter was taken to lure you out of the house, knowing you would be the one to find it. The handwriting on the note matches that of the local clerk, Mr. Jenkins, who has been under suspicion for some time."

"So, Jenkins is behind this?"

"Possibly," Holmes said thoughtfully. "But we must consider all angles. The evidence points to someone familiar with the household, perhaps someone who knew about the secret passage."

I looked around the room, trying to piece it all together. "And the motive?"

"Money, most likely," Holmes answered. "The victim was about to be swindled out of his fortune, and the thief aimed to steal the documents that could expose him."

"Incredible," I said, marveling at his deductions.

"Indeed," Holmes agreed. "Now, we must act swiftly to catch the culprit before he escapes."

He rose from his chair, a determined look on his face. "Come, Watson. We have a thief to catch."

events.title: Arrival at Baker Street and Preparation for the Tale
detailed_summary: They find Holmes in his usual morning state: lounging in his dressing-gown, reading the paper, and smoking a pipe filled with leftover tobacco.
Holmes greets them genially, orders more breakfast (rashers and eggs), and joins them for the meal.
After eating, Holmes ensures Hatherley is comfortable on the sofa with a pillow and brandy and water nearby.
Holmes observes that Hatherley has clearly had an unusual experience and encourages him to tell his story at his own pace, resting when needed.
Hatherley, feeling restored by the bandaging and breakfast, assures Holmes he is ready and will start immediately to save time.
Holmes settles into his armchair, adopting a deceptively weary expression, while Watson sits opposite, both prepared to listen intently to Hatherley's account.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sherlock Holmes was, as I expected, lounging about his sitting-room in his dressing-gown, reading the agony column of The Times and smoking his before-breakfast pipe, which was composed of all the plugs and dottles left from his smokes of the day before, all carefully dried and collected on the corner of the mantelpiece.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes was, as I expected, lounging about his sitting-room in his dressing-gown, reading the agony column of The Times and smoking his before-breakfast pipe, which was composed of all the plugs and dottles left from his smokes of the day before, all carefully dried and collected on the corner of the mantelpiece. He received us in his quietly genial fashion, ordered fresh rashers and eggs, and joined us in a hearty meal. When it was concluded he settled our new acquaintance upon the sofa, placed a pillow beneath his head, and laid a glass of brandy and water within his reach.
“It is easy to see that your experience has been no common one, Mr. Hatherley,” said he. “Pray, lie down there and make yourself absolutely at home. Tell us what you can, but stop when you are tired and keep up your strength with a little stimulant.”
“Thank you,” said my patient, “but I have felt another man since the doctor bandaged me, and I think that your breakfast has completed the cure. I shall take up as little of your valuable time as possible, so I shall start at once upon my peculiar experiences.”
Holmes sat in his big armchair with the weary, heavy-lidded expression which veiled his keen and eager nature, while I sat opposite to him, and we listened in silence to the strange story which our visitor detailed to us.

events.title: Hatherley Recounts the Strange Commission
detailed_summary: Hatherley begins his story, explaining he is an orphan, bachelor, and hydraulic engineer living alone in London.
He details his apprenticeship and subsequent struggle to establish his own practice over two years, earning very little.
Just as he was losing hope, his clerk announced a visitor on business, Colonel Lysander Stark.
Stark is described as exceptionally thin, with sharp features, bright eyes, a brisk step, and a German accent.
Stark immediately emphasizes the need for absolute discretion, citing Hatherley's solitary status as advantageous for secrecy.
Hatherley promises confidentiality, but Stark verifies the promise intensely, checking the passage for eavesdroppers.
Stark's strange behavior and suspicious gaze make Hatherley uneasy, despite the potential business.
Stark offers a lucrative fee of fifty guineas for one night's work, merely requiring Hatherley's opinion on a malfunctioning hydraulic stamping machine.
The job requires travelling to Eyford, Berkshire, by the last train that night, arriving around 11:15 PM.
Stark explains the machine is used in a secret operation involving a small deposit of valuable fuller's-earth found on his property, situated between larger deposits on neighbours' land.
He claims they are secretly extracting their deposit to raise capital to buy the neighbouring lands before the owners discover their value.
The secrecy and late hour are necessary to avoid alerting neighbours or locals about their activities and the presence of hydraulic engineers.
Hatherley questions the use of a hydraulic press for excavating fuller's-earth.
Stark dismisses this, claiming they compress the earth into bricks for removal, emphasizing the need for secrecy again.
Stark confirms the arrangements for Eyford and departs after a final, intense look and a cold handshake.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He looked at me with a last long, questioning gaze, and then, pressing my hand in a cold, dank grasp, he hurried from the room.

events.text_segment:
“You must know,” said he, “that I am an orphan and a bachelor, residing alone in lodgings in London. By profession I am a hydraulic engineer, and I have had considerable experience of my work during the seven years that I was apprenticed to Venner & Matheson, the well-known firm, of Greenwich. Two years ago, having served my time, and having also come into a fair sum of money through my poor father’s death, I determined to start in business for myself and took professional chambers in Victoria Street.
“I suppose that everyone finds his first independent start in business a dreary experience. To me it has been exceptionally so. During two years I have had three consultations and one small job, and that is absolutely all that my profession has brought me. My gross takings amount to £ 27 10s. Every day, from nine in the morning until four in the afternoon, I waited in my little den, until at last my heart began to sink, and I came to believe that I should never have any practice at all.
“Yesterday, however, just as I was thinking of leaving the office, my clerk entered to say there was a gentleman waiting who wished to see me upon business. He brought up a card, too, with the name of ‘Colonel Lysander Stark’ engraved upon it. Close at his heels came the colonel himself, a man rather over the middle size, but of an exceeding thinness. I do not think that I have ever seen so thin a man. His whole face sharpened away into nose and chin, and the skin of his cheeks was drawn quite tense over his outstanding bones. Yet this emaciation seemed to be his natural habit, and due to no disease, for his eye was bright, his step brisk, and his bearing assured. He was plainly but neatly dressed, and his age, I should judge, would be nearer forty than thirty.
“‘Mr. Hatherley?’ said he, with something of a German accent. ‘You have been recommended to me, Mr. Hatherley, as being a man who is not only proficient in his profession but is also discreet and capable of preserving a secret.’
“I bowed, feeling as flattered as any young man would at such an address. ‘May I ask who it was who gave me so good a character?’
“‘Well, perhaps it is better that I should not tell you that just at this moment. I have it from the same source that you are both an orphan and a bachelor and are residing alone in London.’
“‘That is quite correct,’ I answered; ‘but you will excuse me if I say that I cannot see how all this bears upon my professional qualifications. I understand that it was on a professional matter that you wished to speak to me?’
“‘Undoubtedly so. But you will find that all I say is really to the point. I have a professional commission for you, but absolute secrecy is quite essential—absolute secrecy, you understand, and of course we may expect that more from a man who is alone than from one who lives in the bosom of his family.’
“‘If I promise to keep a secret,’ said I, ‘you may absolutely depend upon my doing so.’
“He looked very hard at me as I spoke, and it seemed to me that I had never seen so suspicious and questioning an eye.
“‘Do you promise, then?’ said he at last.
“‘Yes, I promise.’
“‘Absolute and complete silence before, during, and after? No reference to the matter at all, either in word or writing?’
“‘I have already given you my word.’
“‘Very good.’ He suddenly sprang up, and darting like lightning across the room he flung open the door. The passage outside was empty.
“‘That’s all right,’ said he, coming back. ‘I know that clerks are sometimes curious as to their master’s affairs. Now we can talk in safety.’ He drew up his chair very close to mine and began to stare at me again with the same questioning and thoughtful look.
“A feeling of repulsion, and of something akin to fear had begun to rise within me at the strange antics of this fleshless man. Even my dread of losing a client could not restrain me from showing my impatience.
“‘I beg that you will state your business, sir,’ said I; ‘my time is of value.’ Heaven forgive me for that last sentence, but the words came to my lips.
“‘How would fifty guineas for a night’s work suit you?’ he asked.
“‘Most admirably.’
“‘I say a night’s work, but an hour’s would be nearer the mark. I simply want your opinion about a hydraulic stamping machine which has got out of gear. If you show us what is wrong we shall soon set it right ourselves. What do you think of such a commission as that?’
“‘The work appears to be light and the pay munificent.’
“‘Precisely so. We shall want you to come to-night by the last train.’
“‘Where to?’
“‘To Eyford, in Berkshire. It is a little place near the borders of Oxfordshire, and within seven miles of Reading. There is a train from Paddington which would bring you there at about 11:15.’
“‘Very good.’
“‘I shall come down in a carriage to meet you.’
“‘There is a drive, then?’
“‘Yes, our little place is quite out in the country. It is a good seven miles from Eyford Station.’
“‘Then we can hardly get there before midnight. I suppose there would be no chance of a train back. I should be compelled to stop the night.’
“‘Yes, we could easily give you a shake-down.’
“‘That is very awkward. Could I not come at some more convenient hour?’
“‘We have judged it best that you should come late. It is to recompense you for any inconvenience that we are paying to you, a young and unknown man, a fee which would buy an opinion from the very heads of your profession. Still, of course, if you would like to draw out of the business, there is plenty of time to do so.’
“I thought of the fifty guineas, and of how very useful they would be to me. ‘Not at all,’ said I, ‘I shall be very happy to accommodate myself to your wishes. I should like, however, to understand a little more clearly what it is that you wish me to do.’
“‘Quite so. It is very natural that the pledge of secrecy which we have exacted from you should have aroused your curiosity. I have no wish to commit you to anything without your having it all laid before you. I suppose that we are absolutely safe from eavesdroppers?’
“‘Entirely.’
“‘Then the matter stands thus. You are probably aware that fuller’s-earth is a valuable product, and that it is only found in one or two places in England?’
“‘I have heard so.’
“‘Some little time ago I bought a small place—a very small place—within ten miles of Reading. I was fortunate enough to discover that there was a deposit of fuller’s-earth in one of my fields. On examining it, however, I found that this deposit was a comparatively small one, and that it formed a link between two very much larger ones upon the right and left—both of them, however, in the grounds of my neighbours. These good people were absolutely ignorant that their land contained that which was quite as valuable as a gold-mine. Naturally, it was to my interest to buy their land before they discovered its true value, but unfortunately I had no capital by which I could do this. I took a few of my friends into the secret, however, and they suggested that we should quietly and secretly work our own little deposit and that in this way we should earn the money which would enable us to buy the neighbouring fields. This we have now been doing for some time, and in order to help us in our operations we erected a hydraulic press. This press, as I have already explained, has got out of order, and we wish your advice upon the subject. We guard our secret very jealously, however, and if it once became known that we had hydraulic engineers coming to our little house, it would soon rouse inquiry, and then, if the facts came out, it would be good-bye to any chance of getting these fields and carrying out our plans. That is why I have made you promise me that you will not tell a human being that you are going to Eyford to-night. I hope that I make it all plain?’
“‘I quite follow you,’ said I. ‘The only point which I could not quite understand was what use you could make of a hydraulic press in excavating fuller’s-earth, which, as I understand, is dug out like gravel from a pit.’
“‘Ah!’ said he carelessly, ‘we have our own process. We compress the earth into bricks, so as to remove them without revealing what they are. But that is a mere detail. I have taken you fully into my confidence now, Mr. Hatherley, and I have shown you how I trust you.’ He rose as he spoke. ‘I shall expect you, then, at Eyford at 11:15.’
“‘I shall certainly be there.’
“‘And not a word to a soul.’ He looked at me with a last long, questioning gaze, and then, pressing my hand in a cold, dank grasp, he hurried from the room.
